screening_results.reason: The study used resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based social processing paradigm. Inclusion requires fMRI during a social-related task; although participants are within the age range and social variables were measured behaviorally, the imaging does not assess social processing during a task.

Functional MRI study of interactive joint-action (leader/follower) in skilled couple dancers — a social interaction task involving perception/understanding of others. Participants are healthy adults (no clinical groups reported). Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria for full data extraction.
fMRI study using a social task (face evaluation varying race and socioeconomic status) in healthy adult participants (n=61); addresses perception/understanding of others and is not a review.

fMRI study with 16 healthy volunteers viewing and interpreting verbal and non-verbal social interactions, addressing social cognition/perception of others. Not a review; meets inclusion for social-related fMRI in healthy adults. Age not specified in abstract but likely adult; include for full-text verification.

Title and abstract indicate neural (anterior insula) mechanisms of oxytocin on approach behavior toward social stimuli, implying fMRI during a social task. However, the abstract does not explicitly state imaging modality or participant details (healthy adults, ages). Insufficient detail to confirm all inclusion criteria from abstract alone — include for full-text review.

Event-related fMRI was collected while participants performed a mind-perception task (judging likelihood faces have internal states), which targets perception/understanding of others — a social-cognitive process. The study reports healthy adult participants and is an original fMRI study (not a review). Full text can confirm exact age range and sample details.

Study used fMRI in 34 healthy adult participants performing an empathic accuracy task—directly assessing perception/understanding of others (social processing). Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

Functional MRI was used while participants made social judgments (perceived intelligence and friendliness of faces), fitting social perception processing. The abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state they were healthy adults; include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Functional MRI study where participants categorized prosodic expressions reflecting social communicative intentions (social communication). Human participants performed a social-related task; no exclusion criteria met. Abstract implies healthy adult sample; include for full-text review to confirm sample age and health details.

fMRI was used while healthy adult participants (male and female) performed a social interaction task involving others controlling vs free choices. The task probes social cognition (perception/understanding of others, social motivation), fitting the review’s fMRI social processing inclusion criteria.

Study used functional MRI during emotion perception tasks (facial, vocal, bimodal), which falls under social communication/perception of others. Abstract reports healthy human participants (no clinical groups indicated) and presents whole-brain and ROI fMRI results. Not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

Abstract reports an original fMRI study comparing social vs. non-social image appraisal (in addition to an automated meta-analysis). This addresses social processing using fMRI and is not solely a review/meta-analysis. Participant health/age not specified in abstract, so full-text review is needed to confirm demographics, but abstract provides sufficient basis to include.

Functional MRI study examining perception/understanding of social interactions in human participants (task contrasts interactive vs non-interactive and interaction types). Not a review/meta-analysis. Although exact ages not stated, participants are adults; include for full-text review.

This is a theoretical/review chapter discussing social-interactive neuroscience and development, not a primary fMRI study. The abstract does not report an fMRI experiment or healthy adult task-based data; it summarizes existing literature. It meets the exclusion criterion (review) and lacks necessary participant/method details.

Abstract reports an fMRI study in healthy adult males performing social-cognitive tasks (reflection on self and a friend), addressing perception/understanding of self and others. This directly meets the review objective and inclusion criteria; it is not a review or meta-analysis.

Study reports task-based fMRI including social processing in a large sample of healthy adults (Human Connectome Project, n=787). Tasks explicitly include social and emotion processing; participants are healthy adults within typical HCP age range (17–65). Not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI in healthy adult women (ages 25–50) examining neural responses to erotic pictures/videos of other people, which pertains to perception/processing of social stimuli; abstract does not definitively state social-cognition framing, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Task involves dyadic joint action (leading/following/mutual) during fMRI and reports activation in social-cognitive, mentalizing, somatosensory, and reward areas. Participants are trained couple dancers (presumably healthy adults). Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults; full text can confirm exact ages if needed.

fMRI study in 36 healthy human subjects examining perception/understanding of others via observation of cooperative and affective social interactions. Task is social-related; not a review/meta-analysis. Fits inclusion criteria; include for full-text extraction.

fMRI was conducted during a communicative/collaborative retrieval task probing understanding of others (mentalizing), involving healthy human participants. This addresses social processing in healthy adults. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Primary data fMRI studies comparing ATL responses to person-related and abstract social concepts; involves social-related processing (people, social terms). Not a review/meta-analysis. Likely conducted in healthy adult participants. Abstract provides sufficient evidence to include for full-text review.

Primary fMRI study with 20 healthy adult participants performing a social decision-making task (modified prisoner’s dilemma) probing Theory of Mind/social cognition (rTPJ activity). Meets inclusion criteria (fMRI during social-related task in healthy adults) and is not a review or meta-analysis.

Task-based 7T fMRI (rest-task-rest) was used while healthy adult participants listened to attachment-related narratives, examining functional connectivity of social/attachment processing (social approach network). This directly meets inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

Functional MRI study of social evaluation (in-group/out-group politicians) examining vACC during social processing; involves human participants performing a social task. No exclusion criteria met. Abstract implies healthy adult participants and directly addresses social-related processing; include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.

This is a resting-state fMRI study measuring spontaneous brain activity (fALFF). No fMRI data were acquired while participants performed a social-related task; behavioral/social measures (CFS, IAT, vignettes) were separate. Thus it does not meet the requirement for task-based social processing fMRI.

fMRI study where healthy participants judged social properties of biological motion (point-light displays and human-like walkers), directly addressing social perception/understanding. Abstract implies healthy adults but does not state ages; include for full-text review to confirm age range and participant details.

fMRI study investigating neural responses to a social/moral dilemma involving kinship (perception and understanding of others). Involves healthy adult subjects (no disorders reported). Meets inclusion: functional MRI during a social-related task. No exclusion criteria met.
fMRI study of social interaction perception showing pSTS responses to social interaction stimuli in human participants, fitting social-related processing in healthy adults; not a review.

Original fMRI study in healthy adult males performing social-related tasks (IAT re: adultery, go/no-go, and date-rating) probing affiliation/attachment and social decision-making. Fits review objective (social processing fMRI in healthy adults). Not a review/meta-analysis and no patient groups reported in abstract.

fMRI task assessed phonological short-term memory for letters and fingerspelling (sequence memory span), not social processes. Although fingerspelling is a communication modality, the task measured memory/visuomotor processing rather than social communication or other social-related constructs.

Abstract reports a single-case (n=1) fMRI study. Inclusion requires at least one group of healthy participants (age 17–65). A single subject does not meet the 'group' criterion, so exclude based on sample size.

Abstract reports an fMRI study comparing neural activation to romantic (affiliation/attachment) and sexual stimuli in monogamous vs non-monogamous adult men. It involves healthy participant groups and a social-related task, meeting inclusion criteria. Although exact ages/health not specified, participants are described as men (adults); insufficient ambiguous detail warrants inclusion for full-text review.

Direct fMRI experiments on mentalizing/theory-of-mind (social cognition) matching the review objective. Abstract indicates task-based fMRI investigating social brain regions. Participant age/health not specified, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Abstract describes a narrative review on resting-state fMRI and social cognition rather than an original study reporting task-based fMRI data. It does not report human participants performing a social-related task (required inclusion) and appears to be a review article, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

fMRI study examining theory-of-mind (social cognition) processes in human participants; meets review objective. Abstract does not explicitly state participant health status or ages (17–65), so full text is needed to confirm eligibility. Include for full-text screening.

This paper is a quantitative review/meta-analysis using probabilistic atlases to synthesize TPJ activations across studies, not an original fMRI study reporting new data from healthy participants performing social tasks. It meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

Functional MRI study (N=34) investigating social-emotional processes (schadenfreude, fremdscham) and social cognition. Meets the social-related task criterion. Abstract does not state participant ages or explicit health status; include for full-text review to confirm participants are healthy adults (17–65) and meet eligibility.

fMRI study where participants imagined personally familiar others — clearly a social cognition task (perception/understanding of others). Abstract does not specify participant health status or ages; no evidence of exclusion criteria. Include for full-text review to confirm participants meet the healthy adult (17–65) criterion.

fMRI was conducted while participants played the Trust Game (a social reciprocity task). The sample comprised nineteen healthy adults. The study addresses social processing in healthy adults and is not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Original fMRI study examining integration of social information and reward during a group decision-making task; measures include fMRI, reaction time, and gaze. Task probes social influence/perception of others. Not a review. Although participant ages/health status are not specified in the abstract, the study likely used healthy adult subjects; if unclear, full-text review is warranted.

fMRI study examining neural activity during decisions to share news with other people, implicating self-related and perspective-taking regions (social cognition). Participants appear to be healthy adults; task involves social-related processing (sharing/considering others). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text review.

fMRI study using a social interaction task (making listeners laugh) examining self/other processing and ventral striatum, meeting the social-related task criterion. Abstract does not specify participant health status or ages, so include for full-text review to confirm presence of healthy adults (17–65).

Functional MRI was used during an observe/imitate emotional faces task in healthy adult participants (final N=20), assessing emotion recognition and higher-level social inference (TASIT, RAD, Reading the Mind in the Eyes). This directly addresses social-related processing in healthy adults and is not a review/meta-analysis.

Abstract reports an fMRI experiment (17 participants) where healthy adults performed mentalising/theory-of-mind tasks (social cognition). This directly addresses social processing in the brain and is not a review. Participant ages not specified but sample appears to be healthy adults, meeting inclusion. Include for full-text review to confirm ages and health status.

fMRI study examining retrieval of biographical/person knowledge—clearly a social-processing task with fifty participants across two studies. Abstract implies healthy adult participants but does not specify ages (17–65). Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages, health status, and task details.

Abstract addresses neural mechanisms of social information sharing and is relevant to social processing, but does not explicitly state that functional MRI was used or give participant details (age/health). Insufficient methodological detail—include for full-text review to determine fMRI use and participant eligibility.

fMRI study using dynamic face stimuli examining attention to emotional valence and age—clearly social perception of others. Abstract implies human participants (likely healthy adults) but does not state ages; include for full-text to confirm demographics.

This article is a systematic review and meta-analyses of fMRI studies rather than a primary fMRI study with human participants; excluded per the exclusion criterion (systematic reviews or meta-analyses).

This paper is a coordinate-based meta-analysis of fMRI studies (30 articles). The exclusion criteria specify systematic reviews or meta-analyses; therefore it should be excluded despite addressing social processing.

fMRI study in healthy volunteers (n=40) measuring brain response to emotional facial expressions (masked/unmasked), a social-related task (perception/understanding of others/affiliation). Participants are healthy adults; not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient detail to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study in human participants examining attribution of emotions to humans and animals — a social cognition task (perception/understanding of others). Abstract does not specify participant ages/health status; include for full-text confirmation.

fMRI study assessing neural responses to empathy for pain (social processing) in participants exposed to acute stress; reports neural activation and prosocial behavior in (presumably) healthy adult participants. Not a review/meta-analysis and meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study in healthy adults (N=38) performing mental state judgments about naturalistic social interactions, directly assessing social cognition (perception/understanding of others). Meets inclusion criteria; not a review.

fMRI study investigating mentalizing, empathy, and prosocial behavior — clear social-related task and neural measures. Although the abstract does not explicitly state participant health status/ages, it appears to be a typical healthy adult sample; include for full-text to confirm demographics and eligibility.

Abstract mentions neural correlates of face recognition but does not specify that an fMRI was used, the task details, or participant ages. Insufficient information to confirm inclusion criteria; include for full-text review to determine whether fMRI social-task in healthy adults was used.

Article is a narrative review of neuroimaging studies (not original fMRI research). It is a review/meta-analytic-type paper focusing on development across ages rather than reporting fMRI data from healthy adults (17–65) performing social tasks; thus meets exclusion criteria for systematic reviews.

fMRI study examining neural responses during a socially competitive learning task (social interaction/social-referencing). Participants appear to be healthy adults; no clinical sample or review. Task is social-related and conducted during fMRI, meeting inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of face emotional processing—a social perception task—meeting review topic. Abstract does not report participant characteristics (health status or ages 17–65), so inclusion cannot be confirmed from abstract alone. Not a review; include for full-text review to verify sample details.

Functional MRI was used while human (25 female) participants performed a social-cognition task about kin and friends, reporting BOLD activations in social brain regions. Participants appear to be healthy adults and this is an empirical fMRI study (not a review). Meets inclusion criteria; include for full-text review.

fMRI study where participants performed a prosocial learning task (choices yielding rewards for self, another person, or no one). This targets social processing (prosocial behavior/empathy) in human participants with no indication of clinical groups, meeting inclusion criteria.

Study reports task-based fMRI of emotion regulation (reappraisal) of angry faces—clearly a social-related processing task (perception/understanding of others). Abstract lacks explicit information on participant health status and ages; therefore include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and age range.

fMRI study of social cooperation (one-shot prisoner's dilemma) in healthy adult participants examining neural responses related to social reward and understanding others; meets inclusion criteria and is not a review.

Abstract reports neural tracking in perigenual ACC and dorsomedial frontal area 9 during cooperative and competitive tasks, indicating fMRI was used during a social task (self–other perception). Participants appear to be healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (e.g., review/meta-analysis) apply. Include for full-text review to confirm sample age/details.

fMRI was used while healthy adult participants (N=25) viewed attachment-related vs. neutral scenes—a social/attachment task. Meets inclusion: social-related processing (attachment), functional MRI, and healthy adult sample. Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information for inclusion.

Abstract reports functional MRI experiments during social tasks (Prisoner’s Dilemma and Ultimatum Game) manipulating sociality — directly relevant to social processing. Participant health status and ages are not specified in the abstract, so full text is needed to confirm eligibility; include for full-text review.

fMRI study of self-reference vs reference to others—addresses social cognition (perception/understanding of self/others). Abstract does not specify participant health status or ages; per screening rules, include for full-text review when information is insufficient.

Task-based fMRI in adult participants (n=20) during observation of angry vs. joyful social interactions addresses perception/understanding of others (social processing). No indication participants had psychiatric/neurological disorders. Fits inclusion criteria for fMRI social-related processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study with 34 human participants engaging in naturalistic viewing of social interactions; investigates social cognition (DMPFC response to others’ interactions). Participants appear to be healthy adults and the study is empirical (not a review). Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study examining neural correlates of social exclusion/performance evaluation (modified Cyberball), addressing social processing (dACC, AI, precuneus, TPJ, mPFC). Not a review; likely involves healthy adult participants. Include for full-text review.

fMRI study includes a social task (theory-of-mind/social attribution) and reports scanning subjects; not a review. Abstract does not explicitly state participant health status or ages, so include for full-text review to confirm at least one group of healthy adults (17–65).

fMRI study using the Ultimatum Game (a social/economic exchange task) examining cooperative behavior and neural correlates of social attachment and emotion regulation; appears to involve healthy adult participants in a randomized longitudinal design. Matches review objective of fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study with 19 healthy adult participants performing a Theory of Mind task (social cognition: perception/understanding of others). Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI study examining impression updating (perception/understanding of others), clearly a social-processing task. Abstract does not report participant demographics or health status; include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and ages.

fMRI study where participants repeatedly inferred others' emotions (social perception/understanding of others), meeting the review’s task domain. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state ‘healthy adults,’ so include for full-text review to confirm participant demographics and eligibility.

fMRI study examining neural correlates of agentic self-evaluation and endorsement of others’ evaluations (social cognition/perception of self), in healthy adult sample implied; meets inclusion (task-based fMRI of social-related processing). Not a review.

Primary fMRI study examining theory-of-mind/social cognition during cooperative vs competitive interactions — a social-related task. It is original research (not a review) and clearly reports neural measures during social processing; participant group appears to be healthy adults. Fits the meta-analysis objective of social processing in healthy adults. Include for full-text review to confirm age range and health status if needed.

fMRI study with a large sample of healthy adult participants (N=178) performing social-cognitive tasks (empathy and mentalizing). Not a review/meta-analysis; meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

Abstract describes methods for analyzing overlapping brain network communities during rest and unspecified tasks; it does not mention any social-related tasks or social processing. Participants/tasks related to social constructs are not reported, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of social cognition (empathy, perspective taking, attention) during a charitable giving task in human participants. It addresses social-related processing in healthy adults; although exact ages are not stated, there is no indication of clinical populations. Insufficient detail on participant ages in abstract warrants inclusion for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Abstract examines neural correlates of mentalizing and effects of social experiences in adults, implying social cognition processing and neuroimaging. However it does not explicitly state task-based fMRI in the abstract; include for full-text review to confirm methods and sample meet criteria.

fMRI study in healthy volunteers performing a social interaction/aggression (retaliation) task — a social-processing paradigm (response to provocation). Participants are healthy adults (male volunteers). Age range not specified in abstract, but criteria met for inclusion; include for full-text review to confirm ages and details.

fMRI study in adults using a social-related task (socially-induced cognitive emotion regulation with a psychotherapist), assessing attachment/social functioning. Not a review. Abstract implies healthy adult sample but lacks explicit age range; include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study with 38 participants performing a social interaction task (virtual ball-toss) examining neural responses to social reward (ventral striatum). Participants appear to be healthy adults and the task is clearly social; meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study where participants performed a social-related task (constructing and attending to the meaning of their own and others’ LEGO models) engaging social-cognition regions (mPFC, TPJ). Participants appear to be healthy adults and no review/meta-analysis. Fits inclusion criteria for social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study in healthy adults performing a social judgment task (evaluation of social dominance in faces), directly addressing social processing. Participants are healthy adults; task fits review constructs. Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text review.

Primary fMRI study investigating theory-of-mind/processing of unexpected social vs non-social events (social cognitive task). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract does not explicitly state participant health status or ages, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and age range.

fMRI experiment investigating person perception and mentalising (social cognition) in humans, not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract indicates a social-related task and neural measures; participant health/ages not specified, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample (17–65) and other eligibility details.

fMRI study using a trustworthiness ratings task (social cognition/perception of others). Abstract does not state participant ages or explicitly confirm healthy adults; insufficient info to exclude. Include for full-text review to confirm sample characteristics and ages.

Original fMRI study with healthy adult participants (N=37) performing a social-evaluative task (watching approving/disapproving videos). Investigates neural processing of social evaluation, fitting the review’s social-related processing objective. Not a review or meta-analysis.

Block-design fMRI study measuring neural responses to perception of facial expressions (social communication/perception of others). Involves healthy participants (not specified ages in abstract) and meets social-processing fMRI inclusion; include for full-text review.

fMRI study in healthy participants (n=20) examining social-related processing (emotional and cognitive empathy responses to feedback). Fits review objective of social processing in healthy adults. Abstract does not report exact ages, so include for full-text verification of age range and sample details.

fMRI study of affective theory-of-mind (social cognition) with healthy participants (n=21 analyzed). Task clearly social-related (judging others’ emotions). Ages not reported in abstract; include for full-text review to confirm age range (17–65).

Primary research reporting fMRI data during guilt induction tasks that probe social cognition (affect and social-cognitive regions). Appears to involve healthy adult participants; not a review or meta-analysis. Therefore meets inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in adults.

Abstract describes rt-fMRI (simultaneous EEG-fMRI) used to train social communication and analyzes responses in right pSTS, i.e., a social-related fMRI task. Participant health/ages are not specified in the abstract, so full-text is needed to confirm healthy adults. Include for full-text review.

Abstract reports task-based fMRI during live eye contact (a social interaction/perception task) and compares dyadic vs monadic conditions; this fits the review objective. Participant health/age not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and details.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants (N=26) performing a social learning task (judging others' generosity). Directly addresses social processing in humans; not a review/meta-analysis. Satisfies inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

Primary research using functional MRI (MVPA) to study neural representation of others’ mental states (social cognition). Involves human participants performing social-related tasks (thinking about others), and is not a review. Although age range not specified, study likely uses healthy adult participants; abstract provides sufficient evidence for inclusion.

Functional MRI study in adults manipulating social-interactive context (perceived live vs recorded speech) measuring neural processing of social communication/mentalizing; involves healthy participants and addresses social-related processing relevant to review objective.

Empirical fMRI study with 26 healthy adult participants performing empathy-evoking (social cognition) tasks during scanning; investigates neural mechanisms of social/emotion processing. Not a review. Meets inclusion criteria.

Whole-brain fMRI was collected while healthy adult participants viewed and processed faces of other group members—an explicit social-perception/understanding task (tracking sociometric popularity). Fits the review objective (social processing in healthy adults); not a review/meta-analysis.

fMRI study with an explicit social task (control of interpersonal trust/distrust) in healthy adult participants (n=60). Investigates neural correlates of social attitude regulation (perception/understanding of others), and is an original empirical study, not a review—meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study investigating processing of social versus nonsocial gestures and social cognitive/affective processing. Abstract implies non-clinical participants and directly addresses social processing relevant to review objective. Include for full-text to confirm participant ages and health status.

Hyperscanning fMRI study examining mutual gaze and joint attention — clearly social processing. Abstract describes paired healthy participants and social interaction tasks; no indication of clinical populations. Age range not reported, so include for full-text review to confirm participants are healthy adults (17–65) and to extract necessary details.

fMRI study examining neural correlates of speech acts (social communication). Abstract reports task-based fMRI with participants and social-interaction processing; likely healthy adults. Age/sample details not given in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm demographics.

fMRI study investigating agency and communion (core social cognition constructs) using a task-based design—meets review objective. Abstract does not specify participant health status or ages (17–65), so inclusion cannot be confirmed from abstract alone; include for full-text review to verify participant demographics and health.

fMRI study examining disgust perception in racial prejudice addresses social cognition (perception of others) and used a social-related task. Abstract does not specify participant health status or ages, so eligibility cannot be confirmed from abstract alone; include for full-text review to determine if participants are healthy adults (17–65).

fMRI study using the Cyberball social exclusion task (a social processing paradigm) in human participants examining neural correlates of romantic relationship satisfaction. Abstract does not state participant ages/health explicitly, so include for full-text confirmation.

Human fMRI experiment examining self-referential and social stimulus processing (social-related task). Reports neural activations for social processing; meets inclusion criteria. Abstract does not specify age range but implies healthy participants; include for full-text review to confirm participant details.

Primary research using fMRI while participants read literary passages varying in social vs non-social content; probes social-cognitive/theory-of-mind processes and reports dmPFC activity. Involves healthy adult participants and is not a review. Satisfies inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in adults.

Original fMRI experiment in which healthy participants viewed social interactions (violent conflict) with attention to aggressor vs. victim — a social perception/understanding task relevant to the review. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract does not state ages but meets criteria or warrants full-text for demographics and confirmation.

The study used fMRI during an empathy-for-pain task manipulating ingroup/outgroup (minimal group paradigm), which is a social-related process (perception/understanding of others). The sample is 30 healthy participants (adults). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet the inclusion criteria.

Abstract describes fMRI of negative emotion processing and sex differences in fronto-limbic connectivity in adults but does not specify whether the task is social-related. Participant health status appears to be healthy adults but social nature of task is unclear. Insufficient information to exclude; include for full-text review to determine social relevance and participant ages.

Abstract addresses Theory of Mind and mPFC (relevant social processing) but does not state whether an fMRI was conducted during a social task or participant characteristics (healthy adults). Insufficient methodological detail in abstract — include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

fMRI study where participants performed a gaze-following task involving in-group/out-group political figures—clearly a social-related task (perception/understanding of others/social attention). BOLD activity reported in social orienting network. Participant health/ages not specified in abstract, so include for full-text to confirm eligibility.

fMRI paradigm (EmpaToM) administered to healthy adult samples (N=90, N=178) probing social cognition (empathy and Theory of Mind). Task-based functional imaging data relate neural networks to behavioral indices. Not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social-processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study in healthy adult male and female participants examining neural processing of social reputation (a social-related task). Fits inclusion criteria (social processing, functional MRI, healthy adults aged likely within 17–65). Not a review or meta-analysis.

Abstract reports functional neuroimaging (fMRI) while participants viewed social scenes, a social-cognition/mentalizing task linked to perception/understanding of others. Sample appears to be healthy adult individuals and the paper is an original empirical study (not a review). Thus it meets the inclusion criteria.

fMRI study in healthy participants examining spontaneous imitation—an aspect of social cognition (perception/understanding of others, social communication). Meets inclusion criteria (task-based fMRI in healthy adults); not a review.

fMRI study in 164 healthy adults performing an interactive mentalizing (Prisoner’s Dilemma) task assessing attachment/affiliation-related processing. Fits review objective of social-related fMRI in healthy adults; not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info for inclusion.

fMRI study examining mental-state reasoning vs action representation (why/how questions), which pertains to social cognition (perception/understanding of others). Conducted in human participants with no indication of clinical populations; meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults. Not a review/meta-analysis.

Original fMRI study measuring STS responses to a range of social and linguistic stimuli in human participants, addressing social perception and cognition. Not a review/meta-analysis and appears to involve healthy adult participants. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in humans.

Primary fMRI study investigating social gaze processing (perception/understanding of others). Uses an fMRI social task in human participants and reports behavioral and neural results. Not a review/meta-analysis. Although participant ages/health not explicitly stated in abstract, the study context implies healthy adult subjects; thus it meets inclusion.

Abstract reports an empirical fMRI study examining social working memory and social cognitive processing in humans (medial/lateral frontoparietal systems). It addresses social-related processing and is not a review. Participant health/age not specified in abstract, but the study clearly fits the review objective and warrants full-text review to confirm sample details.

fMRI study in young healthy adults performing an incentive delay task with social reward; directly investigates neural correlates of social reward processing. Meets inclusion criteria (task involving social processing, healthy participants aged within 17–65). Not a review or meta-analysis.

fMRI study using an automatic imitation task with social-affective facial stimuli examining affiliation-related mimicry and neural processes. Appears to involve healthy adult participants and directly addresses social cognition/affiliation. Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient detail to meet inclusion criteria.

Functional MRI study examining social (vs nonsocial) attributions and associated brain regions (DMPFC) in human participants. Abstract describes social cognitive processing relevant to the review. Demographics/health status not explicitly stated, so include for full-text confirmation of ages and participant health.

This is a theoretical/review paper discussing explanations of mirror-touch synesthesia and existing evidence. The abstract reports no original fMRI methods, participants, or task-based functional imaging in healthy adults, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports an empirical dyadic fMRI (dfMRI) study of face-to-face social interaction with BOLD results linking empathy/mentalization and default-mode networks. It is not a review/meta-analysis and addresses social processing in humans, meeting inclusion criteria. Participant health/ages not specified but study appears experimental rather than review; include for full-text to confirm sample demographics.

Hyperscanning fMRI was used during a real-time social interaction (joint attention) between human dyads, addressing social cognition. The study involves healthy adult participants and is an original empirical fMRI study, not a review.

fMRI study with 18 human participants performing a social cognition task (predicting others' behavior; ToM and deontic inference). Participants are adult (n=18) and no clinical populations are mentioned. Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study examining neural basis of deception in a game-theoretic social interaction, probing social communication and understanding of others (theory of mind). Abstract implies healthy adult participants but lacks explicit age/health details; include for full-text review to confirm sample eligibility.

fMRI study examining perception of emotions in dynamic crowds (social-related processing). Uses realistic videos probing perception/understanding of others; appears to involve healthy human participants. Not a review/meta-analysis. Age not specified in abstract, but criterion uncertainty is minor — include for full-text review.

fMRI study measuring neural responses while participants judged social person dyads (congruent vs. incongruent interactions). Task is social perception of others; no clinical population mentioned, implying healthy adult sample. Not a review. Meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=37) performing a social communication task (feeling addressed); examines neural processing of social cues (gestures, body orientation). Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports dyadic fMRI during eye contact, a social-interaction task relevant to perception/understanding of others. It does not specify participant health status or ages (17–65 requirement). Because participant details are insufficient in the abstract, include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Abstract reports neuroimaging linking neural activity in mentalizing regions to exposure and retransmission of social language—clearly studies social processing. It likely involves healthy adults. fMRI study in healthy adult participants examining neural correlates of mental state attribution (social cognition) when listening to human-composed vs computer-generated music. No clinical groups or review article indicated; meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

Event-related fMRI study in healthy human subjects performing a social-communication task (gaze- and finger-pointing-following) probing perception/understanding of others. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria for full review.

fMRI study with 18 healthy adult participants performing a social motor response learning task; investigates neural signals related to inference about others' intentions/goals (social processing). Participants are adults (18), within 17–65. Not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI study of emotion attribution (SELF/OTHER) in healthy adults assessing empathy/social cognition—directly matches social-related processing criterion; not a review/meta-analysis; abstract provides sufficient info for inclusion.

fMRI study in healthy human adults investigating self-recognition (face and name), addressing perception/understanding of self — a social-related process. Not a review/meta-analysis and meets age/participant criteria based on abstract.

fMRI was used while human subjects performed a social interactive task (and a non-social control), directly addressing social-related processing. The study reports experiments with healthy adult participants and contrasts in-group vs out-group interactions. It is an original fMRI study (not a review/meta-analysis). Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text review.

fMRI study examining neural responses to social hierarchy (perception of others/status) in an interactive social task with human participants. Fits social-related processing in healthy adults; not a review. Abstract provides sufficient detail to include for full-text review.

Functional MRI study using social-theory-of-mind tasks (cooperation, deception) in healthy volunteers; addresses social processing in adults and is not a review. Fits inclusion criteria; include for full-text review.

fMRI study examining observation and execution of facial expressions and social hand gestures (social communication) in human participants. Abstract indicates fMRI activation in mirror neuron system; meets social-processing and fMRI criteria. Participant health and exact ages not specified—include for full-text review to confirm demographics and eligibility.

fMRI study investigating neural responses to others' actions (social cognition) in human participants; aligns with social-related processing. Abstract does not specify participant ages/health, but likely healthy adults—insufficient detail to confirm age range, so include for full-text review.

fMRI study administering emotional facial-expression tasks (social communication/perception of others) in healthy human participants (n=12). This directly addresses social-related processing and meets inclusion criteria; not a review/meta-analysis. Age range not specified but participants described as healthy subjects (likely adults). Include for full-text review.

fMRI study of a social interaction task probing friendship (affiliation/attachment and social reward) in 28 healthy adult participants. Task involves social-related processing (approach/avoidance toward friends vs celebrities). Not a review; meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study in healthy ‘normal subjects’ performing communicative (social) speech vs description tasks—directly examines social communication processing. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract indicates healthy participants; meets inclusion for social-related fMRI in adults.

Functional MRI study of self-referential processing and perspective taking (social cognition) in human participants; targets perception/understanding of self and others. No indication of clinical sample or review article. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

Functional MRI study in human participants performing a social-related task (judging meaning relatedness of social concepts). Appears to use healthy adult participants and directly addresses social cognition; not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

Functional MRI study of social cognition (viewing social groups) in human participants (n=10), addressing perception/understanding of others; not a review. Age range not specified but participants are adults; include for full-text confirmation.

fMRI study using an interactive social task (competitive reaction-time with provocation and retaliation) in healthy adult participants; addresses social interaction, perception/understanding of others, and affective processes. Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study investigating neural responses to neutral and fearful faces (visible and invisible). Face perception and facial-expression processing are social-related constructs (perception/understanding of others). Although participant ages not specified, the abstract describes a typical human fMRI experiment likely with healthy adults; therefore include for full-text review.

fMRI study examining social cognition (spontaneous retrieval of affective person knowledge) during face perception in human participants. Meets inclusion criteria; include for full-text review to confirm participant ages/demographics.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants investigating neural mechanisms of distinguishing self vs other (recognition of visual feedback as own vs others), which fits ‘Perception and Understanding of Self/Perception of Others’ social processing. Abstract provides sufficient info for inclusion.

fMRI experiment in human participants examining social interaction (gaze and socially relevant facial expressions) and neural correlates of social communication and self-relevance. Appears to involve healthy adult participants and is an original empirical study, not a review. Meets the review objective and inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of social cognition (Theory of Mind and empathy) in healthy human volunteers, meeting the review objective. Abstract lacks participant ages (17–65 criterion unclear), so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Event-related fMRI in healthy adult participants examining processing of angry voice prosody (social communication) and attention in social cognition. This is an original experimental fMRI study of social-related processing, not a review, and meets age/group and task criteria.

Event-related fMRI in 12 healthy adult volunteers performing self-face/familiar-face recognition — a social-related task (Perception and Understanding of Self). Participants are healthy adults (college-aged). Not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants performing a social-related task (impression formation/understanding of others). Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract clearly describes neural correlates of social cognition, meeting inclusion criteria.

Primary data from two fMRI experiments investigating understanding of intentions in social interactions (theory of mind), directly addressing social-related processing. Human participants are implied; although age/health not explicitly stated in abstract, the study meets the fMRI + social task criterion. Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages/health status and extract relevant data.

fMRI study in 19 healthy volunteers performing social-related evaluative tasks (guilt and embarrassment) that probe social cognition/Theory of Mind. Participants are healthy adults; the task is social; not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of social cognition (cooperation vs. competition) in humans, directly addressing social processing. Abstract implies healthy adult participants and reports neural activations during social tasks. Age details not specified, so include for full-text review to confirm participant demographics and eligibility.

fMRI study examining processing of mutual vs. averted gaze—clearly a social-perception/understanding-of-others task in humans. Abstract does not report clinical populations or that participants are excluded; no review/meta-analysis. Participant ages/health not specified in abstract, so full text is needed to confirm age range/health status.

fMRI study in healthy 'normal subjects' who watched realistic social-interaction movie clips—task explicitly involves social perception/processing (interaction vs single person). Fits inclusion criteria (social-related fMRI in healthy adults); not a review.

fMRI study of social processing (judgments of fairness/cooperation) in human participants; reports neural responses to moral/social status of faces. Likely healthy adult sample; abstract meets inclusion for social-related fMRI. Include for full-text to confirm participant ages/health.

Event-related fMRI study where human subjects viewed faces and made trustworthiness judgments—clearly a social-processing task (perception/understanding of others). Conducted in human subjects (healthy adults implied); not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract gives sufficient information to include for full-text data extraction and age confirmation.

Functional MRI study examining social cognition (empathy and forgiveness) with healthy volunteers (n=10). Participants performed social-related tasks (judging others' emotional states and forgivability), directly matching the review objective. Not a review/meta-analysis. Ages not specified in abstract but described as volunteers; include for full-text review to confirm age range and other details.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants (White and Black subjects) measuring amygdala responses to ingroup vs outgroup faces — a social perception/understanding of others task. Meets inclusion criteria and no exclusion criteria apply.

Functional MRI was used while participants performed a social interaction discrimination task (perception/understanding of others). The sample includes a healthy adult group aged 20–41, within the 17–65 range. This is an original empirical study (not a review). Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants (N=30) performing social-emotional face tasks (gender identification of angry and happy faces), which assesses perception/understanding of others. Not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study with 25 healthy adult participants presenting faces vs scrambled images; investigates facial color processing relevant to social communication/perception of others. Meets inclusion criteria (social-related task, healthy adults). Not a review.

fMRI study examining anticipatory interpersonal touch (human vs inanimate hand), addressing social-sensorimotor processing relevant to social cognition. Abstract implies healthy adult participants but does not state ages/health status explicitly; include for full-text review to confirm participant characteristics and eligibility.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (self/other evaluations). It includes a healthy adult group aged 22–31 (within 17–65). It is empirical primary research (not a review). Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria.

Functional MRI study in healthy adult participants investigating brain responses to interpersonal manual touch (social touch). This is social-related processing (affiliation/ social interaction), meets inclusion criteria; not a review or meta-analysis.

Abstract describes a social decision-making task (ultimatum game) with reported neural activations, implying functional imaging of social processes. However participant ages and explicit use of fMRI are not specified and developmental focus raises uncertainty about adult sample. Include for full-text review to confirm adult (17–65) healthy participants and fMRI methods.

Abstract reports participants judged ambiguous social interactions after tactile stimulation and describes neural activations (primary/secondary somatosensory cortices, amygdala, hippocampus, inferior PFC), indicating fMRI during a social-related task in healthy adults; not a review. fMRI study using face vs object viewing (social perception of others) with a continuous sample including adults through adulthood; includes healthy adult participants; not a review. Meets criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI study using a social-related task (perception of biological motion) with healthy adult participants (adults vs youth). Task probes social perception; not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.

Event-related fMRI study examining perception of others’ gender from faces (face gender classification), a social-perception task relevant to ‘Perception and Understanding of Others.’ Uses fMRI in human participants; likely healthy adult sample. Abstract does not suggest exclusion criteria (not a review). Include for full-text review.

Study used BOLD fMRI while participants made social-related judgments (affiliation vs isolation) in healthy human participants (younger and older adults). Not a review. Abstract lacks specific age ranges, so include for full-text verification of participant ages.

fMRI study in humans examining social communication (communicative vs noncommunicative vocalizations) and STS responses; addresses social communication in likely healthy adult participants (not a review). Fits inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI study includes a healthy adult group (ages 25–35). The task involves affective touch, which is relevant to social-affective processing (affiliation/attachment, social perception), but the abstract does not explicitly state a social task — include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Abstract reports an fMRI study using a self-vs-friend face recognition task (perception/understanding of self), a social-related construct. It appears to involve healthy adult participants, but demographics not specified in abstract — include for full-text verification of age/health criteria.

fMRI study examining face identity and eye-gaze perception (a social-communication process). Abstract confirms task-based fMRI targeting social-related processing. Participant health/age not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study of gaze/face processing, which is a social perception/communication task in humans. Authors report neural responses and connectivity; not a review. Although participant ages not stated in abstract, it clearly fits the review objective and likely involves healthy adult participants, so include for full-text review.

fMRI was acquired during a linked social interaction (a deception game) in human participants, meeting the review’s focus on social processing during fMRI. The abstract does not specify participant health status or ages, so inclusion requires full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample (17–65).

Functional MRI study using attributional decision tasks probing self-responsibility and the self-serving bias—core social-cognitive processes (perception/understanding of self/others). Abstract refers to 'normal subjects' (healthy adults). Not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

Event-related fMRI in healthy right-handed adult subjects examined self-face recognition (Perception and Understanding of Self), a social-related construct. Study involves a healthy participant group aged likely within adult range and is an original fMRI experiment (not a review). Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria for the review.

fMRI study with 29 healthy adult participants performing explicit and implicit facial emotion recognition — a social perception/communication task. Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Original fMRI study in healthy adults examining neural responses to images of own vs others' body parts (self- and other-perception). Task targets social-related processes (Perception and Understanding of Self/Others). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text review.

Functional MRI was used to measure neural responses to observed actions (action observation/mirror system), a form of social processing (perception and understanding of others). Participants appear to be healthy adult volunteers. Not a review or meta-analysis. Fits inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports an fMRI study in human participants performing self-judgment tasks (Perception/Understanding of Self), a social-related construct. Participants appear to be healthy adults across cultures; study is empirical (not a review). Satisfies inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI was performed during an explicit emotion-recognition task (social processing) in a group of healthy young adult males (within 17–65). The study is original research (not a review) and meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study investigates audiovisual integration of non-verbal emotional signals (social communication) in humans and reports neural correlates; meets review topic. Abstract does not state participant ages/health explicitly, so include for full-text review to confirm participants are healthy adults (17–65).

Functional MRI study examining direct and reflected self-appraisals (a social-related task: Perception and Understanding of Self). Includes a healthy adult participant group aged 23–30, within the 17–65 range. Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text data extraction.

Abstract investigates neural bases of perception and production of prosody (a social communication function). Title and content indicate neuroimaging of premotor regions in healthy participants and correlations with empathy/prosodic ability, fitting the review’s fMRI social-processing criterion. Include for full-text to confirm participant ages and imaging details.

fMRI study investigating social expectancy violations (perception/understanding of others: warmth and competence) in human perceivers; not a review. Although ages not specified, design clearly uses healthy participants in a social task, meeting inclusion criteria.

fMRI was used while participants performed a social-related task (recognizing emotions and integrating gaze cues). The study includes a healthy younger adult group aged 17–27 (within 17–65). Not a review; meets inclusion criteria.

This is a machine learning methods paper on probabilistic graphical modeling for multi-view bipartite graph clustering; no fMRI or human social-task data are reported, and no healthy adult participants performing social-related tasks are involved.

This is an original fMRI study of identity discrimination of faces (individuation), which falls under ‘Perception and Understanding of Others’ — a social-related construct. Participants are described as human subjects (no clinical groups reported). Study is not a review/meta-analysis. Insufficient age detail, but likely healthy adults; inclusion appropriate for full-text review.

Task-based fMRI study of social processing (empathy/sympathy) in healthy participants. Sample age range 7–40 includes adults within 17–65. Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social task in healthy adults; include for full-text review.

Uses fMRI during a social task (Cyberball social rejection) in healthy participants and includes an adult female group (adults vs. adolescents). Meets social processing and healthy adult participant criteria; not a review.

fMRI study presenting dynamic facial expressions (onset/offset) — a social communication/perception task involving emotion processing. Appears to involve healthy adult participants; not a review. Fits inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI study examining self-, mother-, and abstract-other (theory of mind) processing—clearly social-related tasks with neural measures. Abstract does not specify participant ages/health status, so include for full-text review to confirm presence of healthy adult (17–65) group.

The abstract states this is a literature review (reviews influence of hallucinogens/entactogens) and does not report original fMRI experiments in human participants. It therefore does not meet the inclusion requirement for primary fMRI studies and is not eligible.

Study used fMRI while participants recalled museum displays about World War II, probing medial prefrontal cortex involvement in collective memory and social cognition. This is a social-related processing task in (presumably) healthy adult participants and is an original empirical fMRI study, not a review.

Resting-state fMRI in a sample of ASD toddlers (not task-based) and focuses on early childhood; no healthy adult (age 17–65) task-based social processing group is reported. Thus it does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study examining neural processing of social touch (social communication/perception). Although focused on ASD, such studies typically include a healthy control group; abstract does not explicitly state controls or ages. Insufficient detail to confirm controls, so include for full-text review.

fMRI study using voice stimuli demonstrating voice-sensitive auditory cortex and infraslow BOLD oscillations; voice processing is social communication/perception relevant. Abstract lacks explicit participant age/health details, so include for full-text review to confirm sample meets criteria.

fMRI study where healthy adult participants (n=31) observed goal-directed hand actions, addressing perception/understanding of others — a social-related construct. Includes a healthy adult group and is not a review; meets inclusion criteria.

Original fMRI study investigating neural representations of honesty and their influence on trust behavior — a social cognition task (perception/understanding of others). Appears to involve healthy adult participants and is not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria based on abstract.

fMRI data were resting-state functional connectivity, not a task-based social processing fMRI. Although healthy controls were included, no fMRI social-related task was performed; social cognition was measured behaviorally. Does not meet inclusion criterion of task-based social fMRI.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of facial expression processing (a social task), matching the review objective. The abstract does not clearly state whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included. Insufficient information to confirm inclusion criteria, so include for full-text review.

All participants are adolescents (age 16–17); the review requires at least one group of healthy adults aged 17–65. The abstract does not indicate adult participants, so the study falls outside the eligible age range.

fMRI was conducted while participants (15 patients, 15 healthy controls) played a social task (prisoner’s dilemma), directly probing social behaviour and neural correlates. Includes a healthy adult control group; not a review. Meets inclusion criteria; full-text review recommended.

This paper is a meta-analytic review (combining PubMed search, Neurosynth, and resting-state analyses) rather than a primary fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. fMRI study using an interactive trust game (social reward/ToM) and includes a healthy control group. Controls are aged 13–19; exact number of participants ≥17 is not reported. Age eligibility unclear from abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy participants fall within 17–65.

This study investigates visual gamma activity during a color discrimination task (visual/perceptual processing), not social-related processing. It does not meet the review’s inclusion criterion requiring an fMRI task involving social constructs.

Study used rtfMRI neurofeedback for emotion regulation of the hippocampus in healthy volunteers; it does not report an fMRI task probing social-related processing (e.g., affiliation, social communication, self/other perception). Study used resting-state fMRI (no task). Meta-analysis requires task-based fMRI during social-related tasks in healthy adults. Although healthy controls are included, no social task was performed, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

Resting-state fMRI study of rTMS effects on mFP–amygdala connectivity in healthy adults; no task-based social processing was performed. Inclusion requires fMRI during a social-related task, which is not met.

This is a narrative review/theoretical paper summarizing human neuroimaging literature on the cerebellum, not an original fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. It does not report task-based fMRI data; it is a review article, which meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses or reviews.

fMRI study with 36 healthy participants performing vocal emotional processing (perception of emotional speech), which fits social-related processing (social communication/perception of others). Not a review/meta-analysis. Age range not specified in abstract, but presence of healthy adult participants and task content justify inclusion for full-text review.

fMRI study (N=31) of healthy adults viewing disfigured faces; assesses social perception/empathy and neural responses (ventral occipito-temporal, ACC). Task involves social-related processing (perception/understanding of others), meeting inclusion criteria; not a review.

Primary fMRI study investigating neural processing of social interactions (perception/understanding of others) using multivoxel pattern analysis. Appears to involve healthy adult participants and is not a review or meta-analysis. Meets the review’s inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in adults.

fMRI study in a healthy adult sample (n=51) measuring processing of dynamic facial expressions — a social communication/perception task. No indication of psychiatric/neurological participants and the paper is original research (not a review). Meets inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports an fMRI database including tasks for social perception and reasoning in a sample of 78 participants. Although participant ages/health status are not explicitly stated, the study clearly involves social-related processing; include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult ages and task details.

Primary fMRI study examining neural responses to social exclusion (a social-related task) in a sample of healthy adult participants (N=71 females). Targets social processing (ostracism/affiliation) and is not a review, meeting the review inclusion criteria. Include for full-text review.

Participants are children (ASD and age-matched typically developing children), not healthy adults aged 17–65 required by the review. Although it uses fMRI on a social task, the sample does not meet the age criterion.

Study used resting-state fMRI rather than an fMRI scan during a social-related task. Although it addresses social processing (face memory), it does not meet the criterion requiring task-based social fMRI, so exclude.

This article is a meta-analysis of fMRI studies, not an original fMRI study with human participants. The review’s exclusion criteria remove systematic reviews and meta-analyses, so it should be excluded.

Human fMRI study measuring BOLD responses to perceived animacy from visual motion cues—a form of social perception (perception/understanding of others). Involves neuroimaging in healthy adult participants and is not a review or meta-analysis. Meets the inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI studies.

fMRI study using the Cyberball social-inclusion task (social processing). Includes a healthy control group (n=17) alongside clinical groups, and is empirical primary research (not a review). Although ages are not specified in the abstract, the participant descriptions (diagnosed clinical groups and controls) strongly imply adult samples. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI of social-related processing in healthy adults; include for full-text review.

The study used resting-state fMRI (no task) to examine amygdala network causality across the lifespan. Inclusion requires task-based fMRI during social-related processing in adults 17–65. Although it examines social networks and involves healthy participants, the absence of a social task means it does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study examining socioemotional processing (empathy/anxiety), which fits social-related constructs (perception/understanding of others). Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state healthy adult sample, so insufficient info to confirm inclusion criteria; include for full-text review to verify participant characteristics.

fMRI study with 20 healthy adult participants examining co-speech gestures and their effect on semantic processing — a form of social communication. Fits the ‘Social Communication’ construct; meets inclusion criteria and no exclusion criteria evident from the abstract.

Empathy-related fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=26) performing a social-cognitive task (observing human and robot pain/pleasure). Fits review objective of social processing fMRI in healthy adults and is not a review or meta-analysis.

fMRI study of live reciprocal social interaction comparing human-human and human-robot interactions in a sample of 21 participants; assesses social cognition (mentalizing, social motivation). Not a review. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm participants are healthy adults within 17–65.

fMRI study investigating face perception and recognition (Perception/Understanding of Others) in healthy human participants. Fits inclusion criteria; no exclusion criteria met. Full text can confirm ages.

Study used fMRI during a live social task (mutual eye contact) in healthy adult participants (16 pairs), addressing social perception/interaction and reporting task-related activations and connectivity. Not a review; meets inclusion criteria.

Study analyzes intrinsic structure–function coupling using multimodal MRI in ASD and controls, not task-based fMRI of social processing. No social-related task or task-evoked activations in healthy adults are reported; thus does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study targeting pSTS using dynamic facial expressions — a social perception task (facial expression recognition). Abstract implies human subjects and task fits social processing. This is a rodent neuroimaging study (Fmr1 knockout mice) examining mGluR5 and connectivity; no human participants or social-processing task and thus does not include healthy adults aged 17–65.

Abstract reports task-based fMRI of theory-of-mind (social cognition) in healthy younger and older adults, meeting the review objective. fMRI was conducted while participants engaged in a social task (spontaneous conversation). The study includes a matched typically developing (healthy) control group of young adult males, satisfying the 17–65 healthy participant criterion and addressing social processing in fMRI.

Participants are early adolescents (aged 10.5–13.4), falling outside the 17–65 adult age range, and the study used resting-state fMRI and MR spectroscopy rather than a task-based social processing fMRI paradigm. Therefore it does not meet the age or task-based inclusion criteria.

fMRI study using an interpersonal pleasant touch paradigm manipulating social context (male vs female), which is a social-related task. Includes a matched healthy control group of adults. Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for social-processing fMRI in healthy adults.

Dual-fMRI hyperscanning during an interactive social exchange task examines interpersonal social cognition and brain responses—fits fMRI social-related task criterion. Although the abstract does not state participant ages/health explicitly, the study appears to involve healthy adult interactants; include for full-text review to confirm sample details.

Study reports an fMRI experiment in healthy adult males performing a social provocation/aggression task (Taylor aggression paradigm), assessing neural responses and social-cognitive processing. This fits the review’s focus on social-related processing in healthy adults; no exclusion criteria apply.

fMRI study of trustworthiness appraisal (social processing) comparing BPD to controls; includes at least one healthy control group relevant to social processing. Abstract implies task-based fMRI examining social perception. Age range not specified in abstract, but inclusion warranted for full-text review.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants performing a dyadic social interaction task (iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma). Meets inclusion criteria for social-related task during fMRI; not a review. Information on exact ages not provided but 'healthy subjects' implies target population; include for full-text confirmation as needed.

The abstract describes a multi-method review/meta-analytic synthesis (Neurosynth analyses, lesion work, TMS, MVPA) rather than reporting primary fMRI data from healthy adult participants performing social tasks. It therefore meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

Resting-state (no social-related task) fMRI study; participants are adolescents (mean ~14.5, range 10–18) rather than healthy adults aged 17–65. Thus does not meet task-based and adult participant inclusion criteria.

Study uses resting-state fMRI and intraoperative cortical electrostimulation to map mentalizing networks rather than an fMRI task of social processing in healthy adults. No task-based social-related fMRI in healthy participants is reported in the abstract, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants (double-blind crossover, n=20 males) performing an iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma assessing cooperation/trust while scanned—directly examines social processing. Not a review/meta-analysis.

This is a narrative review discussing resting-state fMRI and interventions in ASD rather than an original task-based fMRI study. It does not report fMRI during a social-related task in healthy adults and meets the exclusion criterion for reviews. Therefore exclude.

This study is not an fMRI experiment and focuses on screening measures for autism in children using questionnaires (M-CHAT-R, BISQ). Participants are not healthy adults (age 17–65), and no social-related fMRI task is described. Therefore it does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants examining social cognition (prediction of others’ mental states) using social-brain analyses. Participants described as male and female; task involves perception/understanding of others. Not a review or meta-analysis. Fits inclusion criteria.

fMRI study measuring brain activity during learning about others’ trustworthiness (social cognitive task: perception/understanding of others). Includes healthy younger and older adult groups; not a review. Age groups not fully specified but younger group likely within 17–65; sufficient to include for full-text review.

fMRI study investigating integration of facial and vocal emotional expressions—falls under social perception/communication. fMRI study in adults using an emotional face recognition task of own child’s facial emotions (social processing: perception/understanding of others, attachment). Includes a healthy participant group (mothers without current mental disorders). Meets inclusion criteria and no exclusion criteria evident from abstract.

This paper is a meta-analysis (activation likelihood estimation across 28 fMRI studies). The exclusion criteria disallow systematic reviews or meta-analyses. The abstract does not present primary fMRI data on healthy participants performing social tasks, so it should be excluded.

Double-blind placebo-controlled fMRI in 55 healthy young men viewing attachment-related (erotic) and fearful social scenes. This is a task-based fMRI study of social-related processing (affiliation/attachment and fear), participants are healthy adults within age range, and it is not a review. Meets inclusion criteria.

Abstract explicitly includes a social cognition task among the tasks analyzed, and uses task-based fMRI whole-brain connectivity. Participant health status and ages are not specified in the abstract, so full text is needed to confirm healthy adult sample and age range. Include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

This is a resting-state fMRI study in young adults with high-functioning ASD and healthy controls; no task-based social processing was performed. Inclusion requires task fMRI of social-related processing, so the study does not meet the primary inclusion criterion.

This is a review article of fNIRS studies in children/infants with ASD (not primary fMRI research). It reviews studies and focuses on clinical pediatric populations and a different imaging modality, thus not meeting inclusion criteria (fMRI in healthy adults) and meets exclusion (review).

This is not an original task-based fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. The abstract describes a review of ecstatic/epileptic phenomena and neuroimaging (clinical populations) and appears to be a review rather than an fMRI experiment with healthy participants performing social tasks.

The abstract states this is a literature review (reviews influence of hallucinogens/entactogens) and does not report original fMRI experiments in human participants. It therefore does not meet the inclusion requirement for primary fMRI studies and is not eligible.

Study used fMRI while participants recalled museum displays about World War II, probing medial prefrontal cortex involvement in collective memory and social cognition. This is a social-related processing task in (presumably) healthy adult participants and is an original empirical fMRI study, not a review.
