fMRI study examining neural processing of social touch (social communication/perception). Although focused on ASD, such studies typically include a healthy control group; abstract does not explicitly state controls or ages. Insufficient detail to confirm controls, so include for full-text review.

fMRI study where healthy adult participants (n=31) observed goal-directed hand actions, addressing perception/understanding of others — a social-related construct. Includes a healthy adult group and is not a review; meets inclusion criteria.

All participants in this fMRI study have alcohol use disorder (clinical sample); no healthy control group (age 17–65) is reported. Thus it does not include a healthy adult group required by the review.

Original fMRI study investigating neural representations of honesty and their influence on trust behavior — a social cognition task (perception/understanding of others). Appears to involve healthy adult participants and is not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria based on abstract.

fMRI data were resting-state functional connectivity, not a task-based social processing fMRI. Although healthy controls were included, no fMRI social-related task was performed; social cognition was measured behaviorally. Does not meet inclusion criterion of task-based social fMRI.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of facial expression processing (a social task), matching the review objective. The abstract does not clearly state whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included. Insufficient information to confirm inclusion criteria, so include for full-text review.

All participants are adolescents (age 16–17); the review requires at least one group of healthy adults aged 17–65. The abstract does not indicate adult participants, so the study falls outside the eligible age range.

fMRI was conducted while participants (15 patients, 15 healthy controls) played a social task (prisoner’s dilemma), directly probing social behaviour and neural correlates. Includes a healthy adult control group; not a review. Meets inclusion criteria; full-text review recommended.

This paper is a meta-analytic review (combining PubMed search, Neurosynth, and resting-state analyses) rather than a primary fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. Although it addresses social cognition among other domains, it meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

fMRI study using an interactive trust game (social reward/ToM) and includes a healthy control group. Controls are aged 13–19; exact number of participants ≥17 is not reported. Age eligibility unclear from abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy participants fall within 17–65.

This study investigates visual gamma activity during a color discrimination task (visual/perceptual processing), not social-related processing. It does not meet the review’s inclusion criterion requiring an fMRI task involving social constructs.

Study used rtfMRI neurofeedback for emotion regulation of the hippocampus in healthy volunteers; it does not report an fMRI task probing social-related processing (e.g., affiliation, social communication, self/other perception). Therefore it does not meet the requirement of a social-related task during scanning.

Study used resting-state fMRI (no task). Meta-analysis requires task-based fMRI during social-related tasks in healthy adults. Although healthy controls are included, no social task was performed, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

Resting-state fMRI study of rTMS effects on mFP–amygdala connectivity in healthy adults; no task-based social processing was performed. Inclusion requires fMRI during a social-related task, which is not met.

This is a narrative review/theoretical paper summarizing human neuroimaging literature on the cerebellum, not an original fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. It does not report task-based fMRI data; it is a review article, which meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses or reviews.

fMRI study with 36 healthy participants performing vocal emotional processing (perception of emotional speech), which fits social-related processing (social communication/perception of others). Not a review/meta-analysis. Age range not specified in abstract, but presence of healthy adult participants and task content justify inclusion for full-text review.

fMRI study (N=31) of healthy adults viewing disfigured faces; assesses social perception/empathy and neural responses (ventral occipito-temporal, ACC). Task involves social-related processing (perception/understanding of others), meeting inclusion criteria; not a review.

Primary fMRI study investigating neural processing of social interactions (perception/understanding of others) using multivoxel pattern analysis. Appears to involve healthy adult participants and is not a review or meta-analysis. Meets the review’s inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in adults.

Primary fMRI study examining neural responses to social exclusion (a social-related task) in a sample of healthy adult participants (N=71 females). Targets social processing (ostracism/affiliation) and is not a review, meeting the review inclusion criteria. Include for full-text review.

Participants are children (ASD and age-matched typically developing children), not healthy adults aged 17–65 required by the review. Although it uses fMRI on a social task, the sample does not meet the age criterion.

Study used resting-state fMRI rather than an fMRI scan during a social-related task. Although it addresses social processing (face memory), it does not meet the criterion requiring task-based social fMRI, so exclude.

This article is a meta-analysis of fMRI studies, not an original fMRI study with human participants. The review’s exclusion criteria remove systematic reviews and meta-analyses, so it should be excluded.

Human fMRI study measuring BOLD responses to perceived animacy from visual motion cues—a form of social perception (perception/understanding of others). Involves neuroimaging in healthy adult participants and is not a review or meta-analysis. Meets the inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI studies.

fMRI study using the Cyberball social-inclusion task (social processing). Includes a healthy control group (n=17) alongside clinical groups, and is empirical primary research (not a review). Although ages are not specified in the abstract, the participant descriptions (diagnosed clinical groups and controls) strongly imply adult samples. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI of social-related processing in healthy adults; include for full-text review.

fMRI study examining socioemotional processing (empathy/anxiety), which fits social-related constructs (perception/understanding of others). Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state healthy adult sample, so insufficient info to confirm inclusion criteria; include for full-text review to verify participant characteristics.

Empathy-related fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=26) performing a social-cognitive task (observing human and robot pain/pleasure). Fits review objective of social processing fMRI in healthy adults and is not a review or meta-analysis.

fMRI study of live reciprocal social interaction comparing human-human and human-robot interactions in a sample of 21 participants; assesses social cognition (mentalizing, social motivation). Not a review. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm participants are healthy adults within 17–65.

fMRI study investigating face perception and recognition (Perception/Understanding of Others) in healthy human participants. Fits inclusion criteria; no exclusion criteria met. Full text can confirm ages.

Study used fMRI during a live social task (mutual eye contact) in healthy adult participants (16 pairs), addressing social perception/interaction and reporting task-related activations and connectivity. Not a review; meets inclusion criteria.

This is a task-free (resting-state) fMRI study examining macroscale connectivity in autism versus controls, not an fMRI scan during a social-related task. Inclusion requires task-based social processing; therefore exclude based on abstract information.

fMRI study targeting pSTS using dynamic facial expressions — a social perception task (facial expression recognition). Abstract implies human subjects and task fits social processing. However participant health status and ages (17–65) are not specified in the abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.
This is a rodent neuroimaging study (Fmr1 knockout mice) examining mGluR5 and connectivity; no human participants or social-processing task and thus does not include healthy adults aged 17–65.

Abstract reports task-based fMRI of theory-of-mind (social cognition) in healthy younger and older adults, meeting the review objective. Age ranges are not specified, so inclusion cannot be confirmed or excluded based on age; per instructions, include for full-text review to verify participant ages and other details.

Participants are early adolescents (aged 10.5–13.4), falling outside the 17–65 adult age range, and the study used resting-state fMRI and MR spectroscopy rather than a task-based social processing fMRI paradigm. Therefore it does not meet the age or task-based inclusion criteria.

fMRI study using an interpersonal pleasant touch paradigm manipulating social context (male vs female), which is a social-related task. Includes a matched healthy control group of adults. Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for social-processing fMRI in healthy adults.

Dual-fMRI hyperscanning during an interactive social exchange task examines interpersonal social cognition and brain responses—fits fMRI social-related task criterion. Although the abstract does not state participant ages/health explicitly, the study appears to involve healthy adult interactants; include for full-text review to confirm sample details.

Study reports an fMRI experiment in healthy adult males performing a social provocation/aggression task (Taylor aggression paradigm), assessing neural responses and social-cognitive processing. This fits the review’s focus on social-related processing in healthy adults; no exclusion criteria apply.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants performing a dyadic social interaction task (iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma). Meets inclusion criteria for social-related task during fMRI; not a review. Information on exact ages not provided but 'healthy subjects' implies target population; include for full-text confirmation as needed.

The abstract describes a multi-method review/meta-analytic synthesis (Neurosynth analyses, lesion work, TMS, MVPA) rather than reporting primary fMRI data from healthy adult participants performing social tasks. It therefore meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

Resting-state (no social-related task) fMRI study; participants are adolescents (mean ~14.5, range 10–18) rather than healthy adults aged 17–65. Thus does not meet task-based and adult participant inclusion criteria.

Study uses resting-state fMRI and intraoperative cortical electrostimulation to map mentalizing networks rather than an fMRI task of social processing in healthy adults. No task-based social-related fMRI in healthy participants is reported in the abstract, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

Study participants are children (NVLD, ASD, and typically developing children); the review requires at least one group of healthy adults aged 17–65. Abstract does not report adult participants, so it fails the age inclusion criterion.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants examining social cognition (prediction of others’ mental states) using social-brain analyses. Participants described as male and female; task involves perception/understanding of others. Not a review or meta-analysis. Fits inclusion criteria.

fMRI study measuring brain activity during learning about others’ trustworthiness (social cognitive task: perception/understanding of others). Includes healthy younger and older adult groups; not a review. Age groups not fully specified but younger group likely within 17–65; sufficient to include for full-text review.

The article is explicitly a review and meta-analysis of social cognition in PTSD (systematic review/meta-analysis). It does not report original fMRI data from healthy adult participants performing social tasks. This meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

The abstract indicates this is a review of task-based EEG and fMRI studies (a review article), not an original fMRI study. It focuses on 22q11.2 deletion syndrome carriers rather than reporting fMRI data from healthy adults. Meets exclusion (systematic review) and does not clearly meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study with a social-related task (recall of relationship episodes) in 35 healthy individuals; not a review. Abstract does not state participant ages, so include for full-text screening to confirm age criteria (17–65).

fMRI study in adults using an emotional face recognition task of own child’s facial emotions (social processing: perception/understanding of others, attachment). Includes a healthy participant group (mothers without current mental disorders). Meets inclusion criteria and no exclusion criteria evident from abstract.

This paper is a meta-analysis (activation likelihood estimation across 28 fMRI studies). The exclusion criteria disallow systematic reviews or meta-analyses. The abstract does not present primary fMRI data on healthy participants performing social tasks, so it should be excluded.

Double-blind placebo-controlled fMRI in 55 healthy young men viewing attachment-related (erotic) and fearful social scenes. This is a task-based fMRI study of social-related processing (affiliation/attachment and fear), participants are healthy adults within age range, and it is not a review. Meets inclusion criteria.

Abstract explicitly includes a social cognition task among the tasks analyzed, and uses task-based fMRI whole-brain connectivity. Participant health status and ages are not specified in the abstract, so full text is needed to confirm healthy adult sample and age range. Include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

This is not an original task-based fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. The abstract describes a review of ecstatic/epileptic phenomena and neuroimaging (clinical populations) and appears to be a review rather than an fMRI experiment with healthy participants performing social tasks.

This is a review article about neural origins of face areas in human and macaque infants, not an original fMRI study in healthy adults. It focuses on infant data and is a review, meeting the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses and failing the adult participant requirement.

Study used non-human primates (macaque monkeys) rather than human participants. Inclusion requires fMRI in healthy humans (age 17–65). Although relevant topic and uses fMRI, participant species does not meet the inclusion criterion.

This is a narrative review (Annual Review of Neuroscience) discussing neural mechanisms across primates, not an original fMRI study in healthy adult humans performing a social task. Excluded per criterion: systematic reviews/meta-analyses (no primary fMRI data reported).

fMRI was used to measure neural responses while healthy human participants performed a social communication task (discriminating emotional valence of vocalisations). The study examines perception/understanding of others and reports STS responses, meeting inclusion criteria. Age range not specified but participants are adults; include for full-text review.

Study uses resting-state fMRI in prairie voles (non-human animals) under anesthesia; no human participants and no task-based social processing. Does not meet requirement of fMRI during a social-related task in healthy adults.
The study used macaque monkeys (non-human primates) rather than human participants. The review requires fMRI studies in healthy adult humans (age 17–65), so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

Non-human animal study (rats) using resting-state fMRI under light anesthesia, not a task-based fMRI of social processing in humans. Participants are not healthy adult humans (17–65), and the study does not investigate social-related task performance. Therefore it does not meet inclusion criteria.
Study was conducted in non-human primates (monkeys), not healthy human adults (age 17–65). Therefore it does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring human participants.
Participants are non-human (dogs). Inclusion requires fMRI studies with human participants (age 17–65). The abstract clearly reports canine subjects, so it does not meet the population criterion.

This is a conceptual/essay arguing for cross-species social neuroscience, not an empirical fMRI study in human participants; no methods, no fMRI data, and no participant group described. Does not meet inclusion criteria.

Participants are domestic dogs (non-human). The review requires fMRI studies of healthy human adults (age 17–65); this study does not include human participants, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.
Study used macaque monkeys (non-human subjects). The review requires fMRI studies with healthy human participants aged 17–65, so this does not meet the population inclusion criterion.

Non-human study (macaque monkeys) using resting-state fMRI; no human participants aged 17–65 and no task-based social processing. Does not meet inclusion criteria for fMRI social-task studies in healthy adults.

Animal (mouse) rs-fcMRI study; no human participants or social task; does not include healthy adult human subjects performing social-related processing. Exclude based on population and outcome mismatch.
Participants are non-human (domestic dogs); the meta-analysis requires fMRI studies in human adults (age 17–65). This study does not meet the population criterion.
Participants were non-human (dogs, N=12). The review requires fMRI studies in human adults (age 17–65). Study does not meet participant inclusion criteria.

Study used rhesus monkeys with single-unit recordings and LFPs in an fMRI-defined area; no human participants (age 17–65) and not an fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. Does not meet inclusion criteria.

The study investigates birdsong and references fMRI in songbirds; it does not involve human participants or fMRI of social-related processing in healthy adults. Therefore it does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study includes human participants processing emotional facial expressions — a social communication task related to perception/understanding of others. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract does not state ages explicitly, so include for full-text confirmation of participant ages and health status.

This is a comparative/narrative review of face perception across species, focusing on behavioral experiments and evolutionary discussion. It does not report original fMRI data collected in healthy adult humans performing social-related tasks, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.
Study used macaque monkeys (non-human) rather than human participants; inclusion requires fMRI in healthy human adults (age 17–65). Therefore it does not meet the population criterion.

This article is a review (not an original fMRI study). Exclusion criterion: systematic reviews/meta-analyses. The abstract does not report primary fMRI data of social processing in healthy adults, so exclude based on abstract.

The study used EEG (mu rhythm) rather than functional MRI. Although it examines social processing (emotion recognition from faces) in healthy adults, the meta-analysis objective is limited to fMRI studies; therefore this study does not meet the imaging modality inclusion criterion.

This is a methodological/narrative review of hyperscanning techniques (EEG/fMRI) discussing advantages and future directions, not an original fMRI study reporting data from healthy adults performing a social-related task. Therefore it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

Abstract reads like a narrative overview and does not report specific fMRI methods, participant numbers, or confirm healthy adult samples. It mentions early fMRI studies but provides insufficient detail to determine if this paper presents original task-based fMRI data in healthy adults. Include for full-text review to verify eligibility.

Single-case neuroimaging study of an 8-year-old with massive bilateral frontal damage (a pediatric patient), not a group of healthy adults (age 17–65). Although fMRI was performed, it does not assess social processing in healthy adult participants.

This is a book chapter/review focused on adolescent development and developmental neuroscience, not an original fMRI study in healthy adults. It does not report fMRI data from participants aged 17–65 and appears to be a review rather than primary research.

Abstract focuses on fMRI during naturalistic movie viewing in 4- and 6-year-old children and mentions comparisons to adults, but does not clearly state adult age range or whether the task targets social processing. Insufficient information to confirm inclusion criteria (healthy adults 17–65 and a social-related task). Include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

Participants are children in middle childhood (ages 8–12). Inclusion requires at least one healthy participant group aged 17–65; no adult group is reported. Although it uses fMRI and a social task, the age range excludes it.

Task-based fMRI examining social exclusion and mentalizing in human participants (social processing). Participants described as healthy male adolescents, but exact ages not provided to confirm they fall within 17–65. Include for full-text review to verify participant ages and health status.

Participants are described as adolescent girls (recruited from reports from 2nd–8th grades), i.e., under age 17, so the study population falls outside the required adult age range (17–65). Although an fMRI risk-taking task was used, the sample age criterion is not met.

fMRI task examining social inclusion/exclusion in a population-derived sample; appears to involve healthy participants and social processing. Abstract specifies adolescents but does not give ages, so eligibility regarding the 17–65 age range cannot be confirmed from the abstract alone. Include for full-text review to determine participant ages and confirm inclusion criteria.

Abstract explicitly states this is a review article. It does not report original fMRI data from human participants performing social tasks in healthy adults, so it meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.
Participants are children in middle childhood (approximately ages 7–13), not adults. Inclusion requires healthy participants aged 17–65. Age criterion clearly not met based on the abstract.

fMRI study of social processing (peer influence via 'likes') in human participants. Abstract does not specify participant ages beyond 'adolescents,' so eligibility (≥17) is unclear. Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.
Participants were children (mean age 10.2 years), outside the required adult age range (17–65). Although fMRI assessed social communication, the sample does not meet the age inclusion criterion.

Abstract describes adolescent response inhibition and gene–environment interaction in context of ADHD; it does not mention use of fMRI or a social-related task, and participants are adolescents rather than healthy adults aged 17–65. Not a systematic review.
Participants were preadolescents (scanned at age 11), outside the required adult age range (17–65) for inclusion. The study does use fMRI and a social task, but the age criterion excludes it.

Task-state fMRI examines self-referential processing (a social-related construct: perception/understanding of self) and includes a healthy control group. The abstract does not report ages of controls (inclusion requires ages 17–65), so full-text review is needed to confirm age and task details; therefore include for full-text screening.

The study reports fMRI in children and adolescents (developmental sample) with no adult group in the 17–65 age range. Therefore it does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring at least one healthy participant group aged 17–65.

This is a narrative review of social skill development in children, not an original fMRI study in healthy adults. It meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses and does not report fMRI data on adults.

Participants were children aged 8–12, which does not meet the inclusion age range of 17–65 for healthy adult samples. Although the study used fMRI and a social task, the sample age clearly excludes it.
Participants are infants aged 4–7 months, not healthy adults aged 17–65 as required by the review. The study population does not meet the age/group inclusion criterion.

fMRI study of neural responses to parent stimuli assessing social cognition/mentalizing (social-related task). Participants are human adolescents with mean age 17 (within 17–65 inclusion range) and appear to be a healthy sample. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text review.

All participants are older adults (mean age 79), which falls outside the required 17–65 age range; abstract provides no evidence of a healthy participant group within 17–65. Therefore it does not meet the age inclusion criterion.
Participants are children (ages 3–5), not adults 17–65; study uses resting-state fMRI assessing intrinsic connectivity rather than an fMRI social task. Does not meet inclusion criteria.
Participants were adolescents aged 12–15 with no adult (17–65) healthy group. Inclusion requires at least one healthy adult group aged 17–65, so the study does not meet the age criterion.

Participants were 63 adolescents (no adult group). Inclusion requires healthy participants aged 17–65; the abstract provides no evidence of participants within that age range. Although an fMRI social-related task was used, the sample age does not meet criteria.

fMRI study measuring maternal neural responses to infant cry (attachment-related social processing) in healthy adult mothers. Task is social-related (affiliation/attachment). Participants are human adults; no indication of clinical populations. Meets inclusion criteria.

The study used fMRI to examine memory processes (working memory and incidental episodic encoding), not social-related processing (e.g., affiliation, social communication, perception of self/others). Participants are healthy adults but the task is non-social, so it does not meet the review’s inclusion criteria.

Participants are described as adolescents aged 14–18 (typically developing). The meta-analysis requires healthy participants aged 17–65; the sample is primarily underage and does not meet the adult age criterion based on the abstract.
Participants are children and adolescents aged 8–17; no adult (17–65) healthy participant group is reported, so does not meet the review’s adult age criterion.

Functional MRI study of social evaluation/impression formation conducted in human participants; includes a healthy young adult group (n=15) likely within 17–65; directly addresses social processing. Not a review/meta-analysis. Sufficient abstract information to meet inclusion criteria.

This is a narrative review/perspective on adolescent social brain development, not an original task-based fMRI study in healthy adults (17–65). The abstract summarizes existing structural and fMRI findings in adolescence and offers speculation; no original methods/results from adult participants performing social tasks are reported, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

Not an fMRI study: methods are focus group and questionnaire (qualitative) with adolescent students. No functional MRI scanning during social tasks and participants are adolescents rather than healthy adults aged 17–65. Therefore does not meet inclusion criteria.

Participants were 11–16-year-old boys (adolescents), not adults aged 17–65 as required by the review’s inclusion criteria; therefore the study does not meet the age criterion for healthy adult participants.

Participants are described as early adolescents (study of adolescent development and sex differences); no group of healthy adults aged 17–65 is reported. Fails the age inclusion criterion despite using fMRI social tasks.
Study used fMRI in 3–7-month-old infants; the review requires at least one group of healthy adults aged 17–65. No adult participant group is present, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

Study focuses on development in early adolescence (longitudinal adolescent sample) rather than healthy adults; no indication of a participant group aged 17–65. Thus does not meet the inclusion age criterion for adult fMRI studies.

Abstract reports an fMRI social task (Trust Game) in adolescents but does not specify participant ages; inclusion requires at least one healthy group aged 17–65. Because age eligibility is unclear from the abstract, include for full-text review to verify age range and eligibility.

This article is a narrative review integrating fMRI and behavioural studies of adolescent social cognition, not an original fMRI study with participants. It meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses and provides no new primary fMRI data on healthy adults aged 17–65.

fMRI was used while participants viewed stigmatized and control faces (a social cognition task - perception/understanding of others). The study includes healthy young adults (presumably within 17–65). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info for inclusion.

Participants were adolescents aged 9–17 (group spanning minors); no distinct group of healthy adults within the required 17–65 age range is reported. Although fMRI social task was used, the sample does not meet the adult age criterion.

Participants were children and adolescents aged 10–17 (no adult sample within the required 17–65 range). Although fMRI and social/moral tasks were used, the age criterion for healthy adults is not met.
Participants are children aged 7–12, not adults 17–65 required by the review. Although it is an fMRI study of social processing, the sample does not meet the age inclusion criterion.

Participants are children (mean age 10.1 years), which falls well below the required adult age range (17–65). Although an fMRI social task was used, the sample does not meet the review’s age inclusion criteria.

Participants were children (7–10 years); the review requires at least one healthy adult group aged 17–65. The abstract reports only child participants, so it does not meet the age-related inclusion criterion.

The article is a narrative review of MRI findings in adolescence, not an original fMRI study. It does not report fMRI experiments in healthy adults (17–65). It therefore meets the exclusion criterion for reviews/meta-analyses and lacks requisite participant/sample details for inclusion.

The study uses fMRI in preterm infants (31+6 to 36+3 weeks PMA) and investigates somatosensory/motor somatotopic mapping, not social-related processing; participants are infants, not healthy adults (17–65). Therefore it does not meet inclusion criteria.

All participants are adolescents (adolescent boys); the healthy control group is not within the required age range (17–65). Therefore the study does not meet the age-based inclusion criterion for healthy adults.

fMRI study of social-evaluation (viewing camera cues) measuring neural responses related to self-conscious emotion—clearly a social-processing task. Includes child, adolescent, and adult participants; adult group age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm adults fall within 17–65.

fMRI study in healthy adults (participants aged 24) involving social regulation during friend/stranger handholding — a social-related task (affiliation/attachment). Meets age and task criteria; not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text review.

fMRI study of social influence (expert advice) on decision-making, addressing social cognition processes. Includes an adult group (18+), meeting the 17–65 age criterion; participants appear healthy (no clinical populations reported). Directly relevant to social-related processing in healthy adults; no exclusion criteria met.

Study used fMRI in 22 healthy adult (male) participants performing social-related tasks (allocentric social hierarchy and social alliance judgments). Participants are within the adult age range; task assesses social cognition constructs. Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.

Event-related fMRI study of person perception/social expectations (social processing). Involves healthy adult participants (political targets) and reports neural results; not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=22) investigating perception of CT-targeted affective (social) touch, a social-processing task involving affiliation/social interaction; not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study (N=61 healthy adult White participants) performing a social impression-formation task of faces varying by race and socioeconomic status, examining neural responses (NAcc, VMPFC, amygdala). It investigates social perception/processing and is not a review or meta-analysis, meeting inclusion criteria.

fMRI study examining perception and integration of faces and voices—a social perception/communication task—performed in human participants (n=20). Not a review. Abstract lacks explicit statement of clinical populations or ages, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult participants and age range.

fMRI study investigating empathy (perception/understanding of others), reporting neural activation during a social-related task in human participants. Not a review/meta-analysis. Although ages aren’t specified, the study clearly fits the review’s focus and likely used healthy adult participants; include for full-text review to confirm participant ages/health.

Study 2 reports fMRI activation while participants viewed sexualized and clothed human targets, addressing mental state attribution (a social cognition task) in healthy adult participants. Not a review/meta-analysis; meets inclusion criteria.

Study used event-related fMRI (with EEG) while healthy adult participants (mean age 29) viewed and perceived others' emotional facial expressions—directly addressing social processing (perception/understanding of others/empathy). Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports neural processing of social anticipation/feedback in borderline personality disorder but does not explicitly state that fMRI was used or that a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included. Insufficient information to confirm inclusion criteria, so include for full-text review to verify imaging modality and presence of healthy participants.

fMRI was conducted while participants (healthy undergraduates, n=46) performed a social task (Cyberball inclusion/exclusion with emotional support). Participants appear to be within the adult age range and represent healthy individuals with varying social anxiety scores. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI was conducted during a dyadic social interaction task assessing social processing and neural connectivity in human subjects, matching the review objective. The abstract does not explicitly state participant health status or ages (17–65); therefore include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI BOLD was acquired during a socio-emotional face preference task (social-related processing). The study includes a healthy control group alongside schizophrenia patients. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm ages and extract relevant data.

Abstract describes a meta-analysis of fMRI studies (and lesion work) rather than an original fMRI study of healthy adults performing social tasks. Per exclusion criteria, systematic reviews/meta-analyses are excluded.

Abstract reports fMRI and behavioral studies of theory-of-mind in first-episode schizophrenia but does not state whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included or provide task details. Insufficient information in the abstract to determine eligibility; include for full-text review.

Abstract describes a narrative/review of naturalistic fMRI approaches and summarizes prior findings rather than reporting original fMRI data from a sample of participants. It is a review article and thus excluded per the systematic review/meta-analysis exclusion criterion.

fMRI study investigating understanding of others' regret (social cognition: perception/understanding of others). Abstract indicates task involves observing others’ emotions using fMRI. Participant health/ages not specified, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.
The article is a meta-analysis (ALE meta-analysis of over 350 fMRI studies), not an original fMRI study of human participants; it meets the exclusion criterion 'systematic reviews or meta-analyses.'

This is a resting-state fMRI study of individuals with autism (ASC) examining intrinsic network connectivity, not a task-based fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. Inclusion requires a social-related task fMRI in (at least) healthy participants aged 17–65; that criterion is not met.

Abstract reports only schizophrenia patient groups (with and without substance use); no healthy control or healthy participant group is mentioned. Although it uses fMRI during a social-emotional task, the review requires at least one healthy adult group (17–65).

Study examines neural signatures of affective self- and other-touch (social-related processing) and includes neurotypical adult controls. The abstract does not explicitly state that a functional MRI task was used, so imaging modality/task details are insufficient; include for full-text review to confirm fMRI and task specifics.

Study used fMRI during social tasks (face processing/affect labeling) with a non-clinical control group. However, controls are aged 10–18 so it’s unclear if healthy participants fall within the required 17–65 range. Abstract lacks sufficient age detail—include for full-text review to confirm age eligibility.

This is an fMRI study in 20 healthy volunteers performing a social-related task (simulating a third person’s feelings/observing others), addressing perception/understanding of others. Fits inclusion criteria; age range not stated in abstract but participants are volunteers (likely adults). Recommend full-text review to confirm ages and other details.

Study examines brain networks in behavioral variant frontotemporal dementia patients and their social-executive deficits; abstract does not report an fMRI task in healthy adults nor include a healthy participant group aged 17–65. Does not meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract is a methodological tutorial on intersubject correlation analysis and does not clearly report original fMRI data from healthy adults performing a social-related task. Information is insufficient to determine eligibility from the abstract alone, so include for full-text review.

The abstract describes an fMRI Activation Likelihood Estimation (ALE) meta-analysis, not an original fMRI study with participants. The protocol excludes systematic reviews or meta-analyses, so this study should be excluded.

Abstract addresses face-processing (a social cognition domain) but does not specify whether an fMRI task was used or whether healthy control participants (age 17–65) were included. Topic is potentially relevant; insufficient information to exclude, so include for full-text review.

fMRI study using an attachment-related baby-cry task probing self- and child-oriented social/affiliative processing in adult mothers; includes a healthy control group (n=15) within adult age range; not a review or meta-analysis.

Abstract explicitly states this is a review of fMRI findings in autism spectrum disorders (systematic review/meta-review). Exclusion criterion: systematic reviews or meta-analyses. Therefore exclude based on abstract alone.

Resting-state fMRI study with no social-related task performed during scanning. Inclusion requires task-based fMRI during social processing in healthy adults; this study does not meet that primary criterion.

fMRI study using the HCP social cognition paradigm (social task) that includes a matched healthy control group alongside first-episode schizophrenia patients. Meets criterion of fMRI social task and presence of healthy participants; not a review.

fMRI experiments examined human voice recognition (social communication/perception) and included matched healthy control participants (adults ~32 years). Study is empirical (not a review) and fits age range and task domain; abstract provides sufficient evidence to warrant full-text inclusion.

The study used diffusion tensor imaging and resting-state fMRI in children (ASD and healthy controls), not task-based fMRI of social processing. Participants are children (not adults 17–65). Thus it fails the task-based and age criteria for inclusion.

Abstract reports neural responses to social/emotional stimuli but does not specify that functional MRI was used nor whether healthy adult participants (age 17–65) were included. Insufficient detail in abstract to confirm fMRI and healthy control group — include for full-text review to verify imaging modality and participant characteristics.

The fMRI task is a simple motor task examining cerebellar function in autism, not a social-processing task. Although healthy controls are included, the study does not investigate social-related constructs, so it does not meet the review objective.

fMRI study using a false-belief (theory-of-mind) task—clearly social cognition—conducted in humans. Abstract reports large healthy comparison groups (480 adults). Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports fMRI in 47 patients with schizophrenia/schizoaffective disorder and does not mention any healthy control or healthy participant group. Thus it fails the inclusion requirement of at least one healthy adult group (17–65).

This study used resting-state fMRI (no social-related task) in an adolescent sample (ages 14–26). It does not report task-based social processing in healthy adults (17–65), so it does not meet the review’s primary inclusion criterion.

Abstract describes a review integrating human fMRI and animal research (a narrative review of social brain circuitry), not an original fMRI study. It meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses (reviews), so exclude based on abstract.

Participants are described as 'youth' (high-functioning youth with ASD and typically-developing youth controls), not adults aged 17–65. The review requires at least one healthy adult (17–65) group; this study does not meet the age criterion.

Abstract describes neural connectivity in autism spectrum disorder and does not report an fMRI social-task in healthy adults; likely resting-state or ASD-focused samples. It does not indicate a social-related task performed by healthy participants aged 17–65, so it fails inclusion criteria.

fMRI study where participants evaluated complex political beliefs, engaging social-cognitive processes (self–other processing, social decision-making). Not a review. Abstract does not report participant ages/health explicitly, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and age range.

fMRI study examining biological motion perception—a social perceptual task (perception/understanding of others)—conducted in both schizophrenia and healthy adult participants. Includes healthy adults within target age range and is an original empirical fMRI study (not a review). Abstract supplies sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.

Participants are children and adolescents (ASD n=40, TD n=38), not adults aged 17–65; no group of healthy adults within the required age range. Therefore the study does not meet the population criterion for inclusion.

fMRI of facial emotion perception is a social-processing task relevant to the review. Abstract does not clearly state presence of healthy adult control group or participants’ ages; nonpsychotic relatives may be healthy but this is ambiguous. Insufficient information in abstract to exclude, so include for full-text review.

Study uses an fMRI task of emotional sentence attribution, a social-related process. Abstract does not state whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included. Insufficient information to confirm presence of healthy participants, so include for full-text review.

fMRI study of social processing (feedback about being liked) in human participants aged 18–21. Sample appears to be a nonclinical/healthy cohort varying in social anhedonia; meets age and task criteria. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info for inclusion.

The study used functional near-infrared spectroscopy (fNIRS), not functional MRI. Although it investigates social cognition in healthy adults, the meta-analysis requires fMRI scanning; the imaging modality therefore fails inclusion.

fMRI study using social-cognition tasks (face processing, emotion recognition, affective ToM) that includes a healthy matched control group. Meets the review objective of social-related processing in healthy adults. Abstract does not report exact ages, so include for full-text review to confirm participants fall within 17–65.

Title/abstract indicate event-related fMRI to positive social stimuli (a social-related task). However, the abstract does not specify whether a healthy adult control group (age 17–65) was included. Information is insufficient to determine eligibility from abstract alone, so include for full-text review.

fMRI study using a second-order Theory of Mind task (social cognition) with 25 healthy control participants (adult age range implied). Meets criteria of social-related task during fMRI and includes healthy adults; not a review.

Functional MRI was used while participants performed a social-related legal reasoning task probing perception/understanding of others (disgust responses and personality descriptions). No indication of clinical samples; fits healthy adult cognitive social processing. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion for full-text review.

fMRI study where participants performed emotion-tracing tasks on vocalizations and music—addresses social communication and emotion perception (social cognition). Not a review. Abstract doesn't specify participant ages/health, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and age range.

This article is a critical/narrative review of naturalistic stimuli in neuroscience, not an original fMRI study. The abstract describes appraisal and discussion rather than reporting fMRI methods or data from healthy adults performing social-related tasks. Excluded per criterion: systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

fMRI study using a social cognition/Theory of Mind task (social attribution) and includes a healthy control group of adults. Meets inclusion criteria (social-related fMRI task; healthy participants present). No exclusion criteria met.

Participants were preschool-aged children (ASD and typically developing children); no healthy adult (age 17–65) group is included. Therefore the study does not meet the age criterion for inclusion in the review.

Study used fMRI during a social-cognitive (visual perspective-taking) task and reports data from a healthy adult control group (n=20). Not a review/meta-analysis. Sufficient information in abstract to meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports decoding performance on social cognition tasks using fMRI data (HCP dataset). It involves task-based fMRI relevant to social processing in (likely healthy) participants but lacks explicit age/demographic details; include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and task specifics.

Participants are described as adolescents (not healthy adults aged 17–65), and the abstract does not specify a task-based social fMRI paradigm (appears to report connectivity differences), so it fails the review’s age criterion and provides insufficient evidence of a relevant task.

fMRI was conducted during a biological motion task assessing perception of others (a social cognition construct). The study includes a group of healthy matched controls (adults). Abstract provides sufficient information meeting inclusion criteria.

Study reports BOLD fMRI during affective and cognitive Theory of Mind tasks (social processing) in a sample of 23 healthy adult participants; participants fall within target age range; not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract gives sufficient information for inclusion.

Study uses fMRI in healthy adult MDs (ages 25–37) during a social task (doctor–patient interaction involving empathy/compassion and reward). This directly assesses social-related processing in healthy adults and is not a review.

fMRI was conducted during a face-processing (social perception) task and results are compared to control subjects (healthy adults). The study includes an adult control group alongside a clinical case, fitting inclusion criteria. Not a review or meta-analysis.

fMRI study investigating attentional and attributional biases (components of social cognition). Abstract does not state whether a healthy adult group (age 17–65) was included or provide participant details. Not a review. Include for full-text review to confirm presence of healthy participants and ages.

Event-related fMRI was used during moral reasoning (a social cognition task). The study includes a healthy control group of adults (matched to ASD group). Not a review or meta-analysis. Fits inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of implicit facial emotion recognition (social processing). Participants described as having high genetic load for schizophrenia (GHR), which commonly refers to unaffected high-risk individuals — indicating presence of a healthy/high-risk group. Task is social-related (facial emotion), meeting inclusion. No exclusion criteria (not a review). Abstract lacks explicit ages, but likely adults; include for full-text confirmation.

fMRI study probing mentalizing (understanding others’ beliefs/intentions) and sensorimotor simulation while participants listened to literary fiction. This targets social cognitive processing in (presumably) healthy adults; include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.

This article is a narrative review of social neuroscience in psychiatry, not an original fMRI study. It does not report functional MRI experiments in healthy adults. Per exclusion criteria (systematic reviews/meta-analyses), exclude.

fMRI was conducted during the Reading the Mind in the Eyes Test, a social-cognition task (perception/understanding of others). Participants were healthy young adult women (n=16), within the 17–65 age range. Not a review or meta-analysis.

Human fMRI study examining neural coding of dynamic social attention cues (direction of observed head turns) in right STS/STG — directly relevant to social perception/understanding of others. Not a review. Abstract lacks explicit participant age details, so include for full-text to confirm sample meets age/health criteria.

fMRI study involving action observation and execution assessing perception of others' effort—falls under 'Perception and Understanding of Others' (social processing). Human participants implied; not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for healthy adult fMRI social-related task.

Abstract reports an fMRI experiment manipulating implied social presence and reports changes in functional connectivity in networks linked to social cognition and theory of mind. This matches the review objective (social-related processing using fMRI). Participant health/age aren’t specified in the abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

This is a narrative review of fMRI reliability, not a primary empirical study reporting functional MRI during a social-related task in healthy adults. It does not present participant data or social-task fMRI results, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

Study involves pediatric participants with stroke (not healthy adults aged 17–65) and examines resting-state connectivity rather than task-based fMRI during a social-related task. No healthy adult task-fMRI group reported; thus it does not meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract describes a review reappraising social cognition in multiple sclerosis and emphasizes neuropsychological/neuroimaging studies. It is not an original fMRI study in healthy adults and meets the exclusion criterion (review article).

This is a resting-state fMRI study (no social task), and participants are primarily severely obese patients (with lean controls). Inclusion requires task-based fMRI of social-related processing in healthy adults; the abstract does not describe a social task or a healthy adult task group, so exclusion is warranted.

fMRI study scanning adults (17 with high-functioning autism and matched control participants) while they thought about 16 social interactions. Includes a healthy adult control group and uses a social-related task (perception/representation of social interactions), meeting the inclusion criteria.

Study reports fMRI during social reward and threat processing and a facial affect recognition task in adults aged 50–60. It includes a matched control group of non-cocaine-using adults (healthy participants within 17–65 range), meeting inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

Study reports fMRI during social cognition tasks (theory of mind) and includes an age-/gender-/education-matched healthy control group. It is original research (not a review). Abstract lacks exact ages, but enough information to include for full-text review.

This article is a systematic review (not an original fMRI study) and synthesizes studies of social cognition training in schizophrenia patients rather than reporting fMRI data from healthy adult participants; thus it meets the exclusion criterion for reviews and does not address fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI task assesses social cognition (inferring mental states from film extracts; language-based social information) and includes healthy control groups (28 HC; reproducibility sample). This meets the review focus on fMRI social processing in healthy adults. Abstract does not state ages explicitly, but presence of adult healthy controls is likely; include for full-text review to confirm ages/details.

Abstract reports task-related fMRI using a social perception experiment and includes a healthy control group (n=21) matched for age; meets inclusion criteria. Study is primary research, not a review. Resting-state data present in addition to task fMRI but does not exclude inclusion.

Study uses fMRI to assess self- and other-reflection (social processing). Abstract does not specify presence of a healthy control group aged 17–65; insufficient information to confirm inclusion of healthy adults, so include for full-text review.

The abstract is a narrative review of semantic dementia summarizing neuroimaging/fMRI findings in patients; it does not report an original fMRI experiment with healthy adults performing social tasks nor state whether healthy participant data are included. It is not clearly a systematic review/meta-analysis. Insufficient information—include for full-text review.

Original fMRI study investigating neural representation of social preference similarity and social cognition—meets topic of social-related processing. Abstract implies human participants performing an fMRI social task; not a review. Age of participants not specified; therefore include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult (17–65) sample and other eligibility details.

Participants are school-age children (ages 9–13). The meta-analysis requires healthy adult participants aged 17–65, so the sample does not meet the age inclusion criterion despite using an fMRI social task.

fMRI study of self-referential processing (Perception/Understanding of Self), which is a social-related construct, and includes a healthy control group. Abstract does not report participant ages—insufficient detail to confirm 17–65—so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility and extract data.

Event-related fMRI study of irony comprehension (a social-cognition/social-communication task). Includes a healthy control group (15 adult female controls) alongside schizophrenia patients, fitting the requirement of at least one healthy participant group aged within 17–65. Not a review or meta-analysis.

fMRI study in healthy human participants examining perception of different laughter types—a social communicative/emotional process (social communication, perception of others). Meets inclusion (fMRI, social-related task, healthy adults 17–65). Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information for inclusion.

fMRI study of facial emotional processing (a social-related task) that includes a control group of adults matched for age and IQ (healthy participants). Meets inclusion criteria for social processing fMRI in adults.

Abstract describes a review of neuroimaging findings in autism (patients) rather than an original fMRI experiment in healthy adults. No methods or healthy control group aged 17–65 are reported; appears to be a review article.

Resting-state fMRI study in MCI/AD patients and healthy controls; no task-based social processing paradigm reported. Does not assess social-related processing in healthy adults during a social task, so it fails inclusion criteria.

This article is explicitly a review (‘In this review’) of eye/gaze processing and neuroimaging findings rather than an original fMRI study reporting new data. Exclusion criterion: systematic reviews or meta-analyses—therefore excluded.

Study uses fMRI of dynamic face processing (a social-related task). Abstract does not specify whether a healthy control group (ages 17–65) was included. Insufficient information to confirm presence of healthy participants — include for full-text review.

fMRI study with healthy late-adolescent participants (ages 18–22) performing a social-related task (observing others’ risk-taking vs safe actions) that probes social cognition and emotional processing. Participants fall within the 17–65 range and study is original research, not a review. Abstract provides sufficient evidence to include for full-text review.

Resting-state fMRI study without participants performing any social-related task; although healthy control group included, no task-based social processing was assessed, so it does not meet the primary inclusion criterion.

This is a review/proposal on deep brain stimulation for severe autism and discusses pathophysiology and a reported DBS case. It does not report an fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults or include task-based fMRI data, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

Study used fMRI to examine Theory of Mind (a social cognition task), and included a healthy comparison group. It involves human participants and addresses social-related processing in adults; it is not a review. Abstract provides sufficient detail to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study examining social perception tasks (videos, point-light displays, moving shapes portraying social interactions) with a typically developing (healthy) comparison group. Abstract labels participants as adolescents but gives no ages, so inclusion per age criterion is unclear; include for full-text review to confirm ages and participant details.

Participants are adolescents (typically developing adolescents and adolescents with TBI), not adults aged 17–65. Although the study used fMRI during a social cognition task and included a healthy group, the age eligibility criterion for the review is not met.

fMRI study of empathy for pain (social cognition/perception of others) conducted during task. Includes a healthy young participant group aged 20–30 (within 17–65 requirement). Not a review/meta-analysis. Sufficient information in abstract to meet inclusion criteria.

Participants are individuals with a psychotic disorder; abstract does not report any healthy control group (age 17–65). Therefore it does not meet the requirement of including at least one healthy participant group.

Hyperscanning fMRI during joint attention—a social cognition task (understanding others). Not a review. Abstract does not specify participant ages/health, so include for full-text review to confirm participants are healthy adults (17–65).

fMRI was conducted during a social-related task (response to facial expressions/emotion). The study includes a healthy control group (controls with no family history of autism). Abstract does not report participant ages, so full text should confirm age range, but no exclusion criteria are met based on abstract.

All participants were patients with amnestic mild cognitive impairment (a-MCI); no group of healthy adults (age 17–65) is reported. Inclusion requires at least one healthy participant group, so the study does not meet the criteria despite using face-name stimuli related to social/emotional processing.

Empirical fMRI study using a social cognitive (Theory of Mind) task (Why/How) with human participants; investigates perception/understanding of others. Not a review/meta-analysis and fits inclusion criteria for healthy adult samples.

fMRI study in healthy adult mothers viewing images of their own and unfamiliar child/dog, addressing affiliation/attachment and social processing. Participants are healthy adults (mothers) performing a social-related task; not a review. Meets inclusion criteria.

The study used resting-state fMRI (no task), whereas inclusion requires functional MRI conducted while participants performed a social-related task. Although participants were healthy adults and the study examines oxytocin effects, the abstract reports no social task-based fMRI, so it should be excluded.

Study used resting-state fMRI after oxytocin/placebo and did not involve participants performing a social-related task. Inclusion requires task-based fMRI of social processing, so primary criterion is not met.

fMRI study of self–other social processing (semantic judgments about self vs other) including a matched typically developing healthy adult control group (ages: young adults). Task falls under Perception/Understanding of Self and Others; not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info to include.

This paper is a meta-analysis/systematic review (analyzed >200 fMRI studies) rather than an original fMRI study of participants; the exclusion criteria specify systematic reviews/meta-analyses, so it should be excluded.

This is a narrative review/chapter summarizing oxytocin research in schizophrenia spectrum; it is not a primary fMRI study reporting task-based data in healthy adults. It also meets the exclusion criterion for reviews/meta-analyses and does not clearly report fMRI social-task results in healthy 17–65-year-old participants.

Abstract investigates neurobiological correlates of social-cognitive alterations in psychopathy but does not specify whether fMRI was used or if a healthy control group is included. Insufficient information in abstract alone—include for full-text review to confirm fMRI and healthy participants.

Participants are Korean children (ASD and typically developing children); no healthy adult (age 17–65) group is reported. The review requires at least one healthy adult group; thus the study does not meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports fMRI (dual‑fMRI) during cooperative and competitive social interactions, directly addressing social processing. The methods indicate healthy adult tasks but do not specify participant ages or explicit health status; therefore include for full‑text review to confirm eligibility (age 17–65 and healthy participants).

fMRI study of face processing (social perception/understanding of others) with a healthy control group (n=21). Task involves encoding and recognition of faces, a social-related task. Participants appear to be adults; study is original research, not a review.

Study used only forensic psychiatric participants (psychotic and nonpsychotic criminal offenders); no group of healthy adults (age 17–65) is reported. Therefore it does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring at least one healthy participant group.

This study is a multimodal coordinate-based meta-analysis (CBMA) of fMRI and VBM studies in first-degree relatives of schizophrenia patients, i.e., a meta-analysis rather than an original fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. It therefore meets the exclusion criterion for meta-analyses.

Abstract investigates biological motion/social cognition and includes an age-matched healthy control group (N=67). However, the abstract does not state that functional MRI was used (method unclear). Because modality is uncertain but the study otherwise meets topic and participant criteria, include for full-text review to verify fMRI use.

fMRI study examining self-knowledge (social cognition) while participants made self-descriptiveness judgments — meets social-related task criterion. Appears to involve healthy adult participants (no clinical population indicated) and is not a review. Age range not specified in abstract; include for full-text verification.

Randomized within-subject fMRI in 40 healthy adult males assessing neural and emotional responses to interpersonal touch (social communication). Fits social-related processing in healthy adults and is an original empirical study, not a review.

fMRI study of cortical processing of vocal (socially relevant) sounds; includes individuals with autism and control participants. Abstract does not report participant ages or confirm a healthy adult (17–65) group. Insufficient age information — include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

This fMRI study investigates memory retrieval and white-matter connectivity within ventrolateral prefrontal cortex, not social-related processing. It does not report an fMRI task involving social constructs, so it does not meet the review’s inclusion criteria.

Healthy adult participants (right-handed males, age within 17–65), underwent fMRI during a validated social cognition/ToM task (Reading the Mind in the Eyes). Study reports task-related brain activation; not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing.

fMRI study of mentalizing (social cognition) involving reflective judgments about self/other — a social-related task. Includes a group of healthy adult controls (33, age- and IQ-matched). Not a review or meta-analysis.

This article is a meta-analysis of neural correlates in ASD and schizophrenia rather than an original fMRI study of participants. The exclusion criterion (systematic reviews or meta-analyses) is clearly met, so it should be excluded.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of social cognition tasks and includes unaffected siblings (healthy participants), matching the review objective. Age range not specified in abstract; include for full-text review to confirm ages and extract data.

Functional MRI was used while participants made charitable donation decisions—an explicit social decision-making/altruism task relevant to social processing (affiliation/understanding of others). Participants appear to be healthy adults; not a review or meta-analysis. Fits inclusion criteria; include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and details.

fMRI study where adult participants (healthy control group included) viewed dynamic emotional facial expressions — a social perception/communication task. Participants are adults (likely within 17–65). Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets the inclusion criteria.

Narrative review discussing facial affect processing and fMRI literature in schizophrenia rather than reporting original fMRI data from human participants. No evidence of an fMRI experiment with healthy adults performing a social task; does not meet primary inclusion criteria.

The study uses fMRI to examine face processing (a social-related task). The abstract specifies adults with Asperger syndrome but does not state whether a healthy control group was included; information is insufficient to determine presence of healthy participants. Include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Abstract describes fMRI studies of social perception including typically developing adults engaged in analysis of others’ actions/intentions. However, it is unclear whether this paper reports primary fMRI data or is an overview. Include for full-text review to confirm presence of task-based fMRI data on healthy adults (age 17–65) and extractable results.

The study used resting-state fMRI (no task) from ABIDE comparing ASD and controls. The review requires task-based fMRI of social processing in healthy adults. Although healthy controls were included, no social-related task was performed, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract describes a network analysis of functional brain connectivity related to familial risk for psychosis; it does not report an fMRI social-related task or social processing measures. Focus is on dysconnectivity/psychosis risk, not social cognition. Insufficient evidence of a social task, so exclude.

fMRI study in (presumably) healthy adult participants performing a narrative-reading task. Reported activations in medial frontal and temporo-parietal regions linked to social cognition and predictive inference, corresponding to 'perception and understanding of others'. No exclusion criteria met in the abstract.

fMRI was used while participants performed a social-related task (praying), involving recruitment of social cognition regions. Participants are healthy adults (Danish Christians). Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.
This paper is a voxel-based meta-analysis of fMRI studies (meta-analysis/systematic review), and the exclusion criteria explicitly exclude systematic reviews or meta-analyses.

Study focuses on schizophrenia patients receiving cognitive enhancement therapy; abstract does not mention any healthy adult control group (age 17–65) nor explicitly describe an fMRI social-related task. Therefore it does not meet inclusion criteria.
The article is a large-scale meta-analysis of fMRI studies, which meets the exclusion criterion excluding systematic reviews and meta-analyses rather than primary fMRI studies in healthy adults.

Study reports fMRI during an empathy task (a social cognition process) and explicitly includes a healthy control group. Although participant ages are not specified in the abstract, there is no exclusion criterion met. Include for full-text review to confirm healthy participants’ ages and extract relevant data.

This study is a coordinate-based Activation Likelihood Estimation (ALE) meta-analysis, not a primary fMRI study. The exclusion criteria disallow systematic reviews or meta-analyses. Although healthy controls are discussed, no original fMRI data collection in healthy participants is reported in the abstract.

fMRI study of verbal irony engaging Theory-of-Mind network (social communication / perception of others). Human neuroimaging task clearly social; likely healthy adult participants though ages/health not specified in abstract. Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.

This is a selective/narrative review rather than an original fMRI study reporting new data. The abstract does not describe a functional MRI experiment with healthy adult participants performing a social-related task; it synthesizes existing literature, meeting the exclusion criterion for reviews.

Title indicates this is a multilevel kernel density fMRI analysis (a meta-analytic approach) synthesizing existing fMRI studies rather than reporting original fMRI scans on participants. Exclusion criterion disallows systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

fMRI study examining decoding of vocal emotions (social communication/perception of others) in auditory cortex. This involves social-related processing; likely conducted in healthy adult participants. Abstract lacks explicit participant age/health, so include for full-text review to confirm demographics and eligibility.

Abstract reports fMRI during an affective theory-of-mind task in 25 unmedicated chronic depression patients; no healthy participant group is described. Inclusion requires at least one healthy adult group (17–65).

fMRI study measuring mothers’ neural responses to emotional expressions of their own children (social/attachment/emotion perception), involving adult participants (mothers). Not a review/meta-analysis and meets inclusion criteria for social-related task in healthy adults.

fMRI study where participants viewed cooperative versus noncooperative interactions (social perception/theory-of-mind task). Includes a group of healthy matched controls (n=19). Not a review/meta-analysis. Fits review objective of social-related fMRI in healthy adults; age not stated but controls are matched adults—include for full-text review.

This is a review/chapter summarizing oxytocin effects in ASD and neuroimaging evidence rather than an original fMRI study. It appears to be a review (not primary data) and does not report fMRI results from healthy adult participants, thus meeting the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews.

Abstract explicitly states this is a mini-review integrating multimodal MRI evidence; it is a review article rather than an original fMRI study with human participants performing social tasks. No primary fMRI task data in healthy adults is reported. Exclude per exclusion criterion for reviews.

Participants are adolescents (mean ages 15.8 and 16.2), below the required 17–65 adult age range; no healthy adult group is included. Thus the study does not meet the age/participant criteria for inclusion.

This is a resting-state fMRI study in ultra-high-risk (UHR) individuals with no task-based social processing reported and no clear group of healthy adults (17–65). Does not meet inclusion criteria requiring fMRI during a social-related task and presence of healthy adult participants.

Event-related fMRI study of social cognition (eye gaze processing/understanding others’ intentions) that included a group of neurologically normal/typically developing participants (n=9). Task is social-related and not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.

Abstract describes a review of neuroimaging and behavioral studies in high-functioning autism (a review article), not an original fMRI study in healthy adults; thus meets exclusion criterion for reviews and does not clearly include fMRI data from healthy participants.

fMRI performed during a social-related task (social reflection: judgments about self/others) in a group of 22 healthy participants, fitting the inclusion criteria for social processing in healthy adults. Not a review/meta-analysis.

Study used fMRI during a social vs non-social picture task and includes a matched healthy control group (n=14), addressing social-related processing. Abstract lacks explicit participant ages, so include for full-text review to confirm age range and extract data.

This fMRI study examined processing of emotional faces, a social perception/understanding of others task, using healthy human participants (single-subject data). It is an original empirical study (not a review) and fits the review’s social-related processing criterion.

fMRI face-encoding task probes social processing (face perception/encoding). Study includes an age- and gender-matched control group of healthy participants. Abstract does not specify participants' ages (17–65 criterion unconfirmed), so include for full-text review to verify age eligibility.

The study used near-infrared spectroscopy (NIRS), not functional MRI. Although it examined social-related processing in typically developed adults, the meta-analysis requires fMRI studies; thus it does not meet the imaging modality inclusion criterion.

The article is explicitly a review of neuroimaging studies (title and abstract state it is a review) rather than an original fMRI study of healthy adults. Per exclusion criteria (systematic reviews/meta-analyses), it should be excluded.

Abstract does not specify whether an fMRI task was used or if healthy adult participants were included. Title suggests neuroimaging in PTSD but methods and sample details are missing. Include for full-text review to confirm the presence of an fMRI social task and at least one healthy 17–65 group.
Resting-state fMRI in children (age 7–12) including an autism clinical group; not a task-based social processing fMRI study nor in healthy adults aged 17–65. Does not meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports neural responses to social interaction images (a social-related stimulus) in remitted depression, implying an fMRI task and likely includes a healthy control group. The abstract does not explicitly state fMRI or participant ages, so full-text review is needed to confirm scanner use and age range.

This study used resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based social processing paradigm. The meta-analysis requires fMRI during a social-related task in (healthy) adults; although healthy controls are included, no social task was performed. Therefore it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

Functional MRI in 15 healthy adult males assessing amygdala responses to fear-inducing stimuli after oxytocin vs placebo; authors frame findings in terms of social cognition and trust. Meets criterion of fMRI in healthy adults with social-related processing (or at least strongly linked to social cognition). Abstract ambiguity about stimulus socialness means full-text review is appropriate.

This is a resting-state fMRI study of low-frequency fluctuations in schizophrenia and healthy controls, not a task-based study of social processing. It does not report a social-related task in healthy adults, so it fails the inclusion criterion requiring task-based social processing.

fMRI study using emotional face (social) and letter tasks; includes a neurotypical control group (healthy participants). Abstract does not state participant ages, so include for full-text review to confirm ages (17–65) and other eligibility details.

The study used resting-state BOLD fMRI rather than a task-based social processing paradigm. Inclusion requires an fMRI scan while participants performed a social-related task; resting-state connectivity does not meet this criterion despite examining social-cognition-related regions and including healthy adults.
Participants are children aged 7–12; no group of healthy adults within the required 17–65 age range is included. Therefore the study does not meet the inclusion age criterion for the meta-analysis.

fMRI was used in two studies with healthy young adults performing a social attribution task (perception of human-like interactions), which is a social-processing paradigm.
