Participants are healthy adults (within 17–65). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text review.

fMRI study of social cognition (trustworthiness and age judgments) with a nonclinical control group. Meets review objective (social-related processing) and includes healthy participants; abstract implies adult men. No exclusion criteria met. Full text should be checked for exact ages and task details.

The study used fMRI during a social cognition task (direct vs averted gaze) and included a healthy control group (16 healthy subjects). Fits review objective of social processing in healthy adults. Age range not specified in the abstract, so full text should be checked, but inclusion is justified based on available information.

fMRI study using a virtual social cognition task (social-related processing) that includes a healthy control group. Abstract does not report participant ages (17–65 criterion unclear), so include for full-text review to confirm age range and other eligibility details.

fMRI study using social (trust) games and includes a healthy control group. Abstract does not specify participants' ages (17–65 criterion not explicit), so include for full-text review to confirm age range and other details.

Abstract describes fMRI using real-time eyetracking to create gaze-contingent stimuli and reports two paradigms where participants interact with a virtual other, indicating functional MRI during social-related tasks in human participants. Although ages/health status not specified, the study meets the core criterion and should be included for full-text review.

fMRI study with healthy adult subjects examining event simulation that explicitly references social-cognition processes (mentalizing/trait inference). Meets inclusion criteria (social-related processing, fMRI, healthy participants). No exclusion criteria met.

fMRI study with both schizophrenia patients and healthy control participants who passively viewed a cinematic social-affective scene (ToM/embodied simulation). This is a social-related task and includes healthy adults; not a review. Meets inclusion criteria.

The study reports fMRI during a social-cognitive task (affective ToM, emotion recognition) and includes a matched healthy control group (n=22), meeting the review’s criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults. Not a review.

The article is an fMRI meta-analysis/systematic review (title and abstract indicate meta-analysis) rather than a primary fMRI study. Exclusion criterion 'systematic reviews or meta-analyses' is met; abstract provides no original participant-level fMRI data.

fMRI study using a social cognition task (Theory of Mind/empathy) with 70 human subjects; not a review. Although ages/health status are not explicitly stated, the study appears to classify social anhedonia within a nonclinical/healthy sample and meets the review’s social-processing fMRI criterion. Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.

fMRI study of healthy adult participants (registered Democrats and Republicans) while viewing faces of presidential candidates, addressing social perception/affiliation and emotional responses—fits social-related processing in healthy adults. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text review.

The study reports an fMRI social-judgment task (social acceptance/rejection) and includes a matched healthy control group alongside patients, matching the review objective. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text review.

Abstract reports results from two social-cognitive functional MRI tasks showing STS activity related to OXT methylation, meeting the fMRI social-processing criterion. The abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state they are healthy adults, so inclusion for full-text review is warranted to confirm eligibility.

Abstract addresses social cognition and amygdala connectivity but does not specify whether fMRI was task-based or whether healthy adult participants (age 17–65) were included. Insufficient information to determine eligibility from abstract alone—include for full-text review.

This is a narrative review describing fMRI use in infants and early brain development, not an original fMRI study in healthy adults (17–65). It meets the exclusion criterion for reviews/meta-analyses and thus should be excluded.

The study used resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based fMRI involving social-related processing. Although healthy controls were included, the absence of a social task means it does not meet the primary inclusion criterion.

The study reports fMRI in 17 young adults with high-functioning ASD and aims to predict treatment response; the abstract does not mention any healthy control group. Fails inclusion criterion requiring at least one group of healthy participants (age 17–65). Not a review.

The study reports dual MEG (magnetoencephalography) recordings rather than functional MRI. Inclusion requires fMRI data collected during social-related tasks in humans; modality mismatch excludes the study.

fMRI study using a facial affect matching task (social cue processing of others) and includes a healthy adult comparison group (12 participants), fitting the review's social-processing task criterion and age range. Not a review or meta-analysis.
Resting-state fMRI study comparing MDD patients and healthy controls; no task-based social processing was performed. Does not meet inclusion criterion requiring an fMRI social-related task.

fMRI study reporting behavioral and fMRI findings in a sample of 22 typically developing adults performing a social attribution/mentalizing task using the DISC stimuli. Meets criteria: functional MRI during social processing in healthy adults (age range likely within 17–65). Not a review.

Concurrent EEG-fMRI was used while participants performed a group categorization task examining processing of emotional faces and effects of arbitrary group membership — clearly a social-related task. Study appears to involve healthy adult participants and is not a review/meta-analysis. Satisfies inclusion criteria (fMRI during social task).

This paper is a quantitative review/meta-analysis of fMRI studies in individuals at clinical high risk for psychosis. Exclusion criteria disallow systematic reviews/meta-analyses. Although it discusses social cognition paradigms and healthy controls, it is not an original fMRI study of healthy adults.

The article is a review (states 'In this review') summarizing fMRI literature rather than reporting original fMRI data from participants. Exclusion criterion: systematic reviews/meta-analyses — exclude.

fMRI study in healthy adults (n=24) performing a social interaction task (self- and other-initiated joint attention). Addresses social processing and uses functional MRI; not a review. Meets inclusion criteria.

Participants are children/adolescents (ASD and typically developing), not healthy adults aged 17–65 required by the review inclusion criteria. Although the task is social-related, the age criterion is not met, so the study should be excluded.

fMRI study examining visual short-term memory for emotional (angry) faces—a social perception/understanding of others task. Not a review. Abstract does not report participant ages explicitly; insufficient to confirm age range, so include for full-text review.

fMRI study where subjects encoded facts about unfamiliar people and showed person-selective ATL responses and connectivity with the social cognition network, addressing social-related processing. Abstract suggests healthy adult participants but does not specify ages; include for full-text to confirm participant ages/health status.

Pharmaco-fMRI study in healthy adult men and women (N=304) conducted while participants played the iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma — a social interaction task probing social processing. Fits review objective of fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults; not a review article. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text data extraction.

The study used fMRI (with MEG) while participants viewed dynamic facial expressions—a social cognition task (perception/understanding of others). The abstract reports task-related BOLD responses and behavioral correlations. Participant health status/ages are not specified in the abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm inclusion criteria.

fMRI study examines neural responses to social stimuli (emotional facial expressions) in Williams syndrome participants and compared with controls, satisfying the social-related task criterion. Abstract mentions control group but does not specify whether controls are healthy adults aged 17–65. Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.

Participants are described as adolescents/youth (socially anxious and healthy youth). The review requires at least one group of healthy adults aged 17–65; the abstract provides no evidence that participants are adults. Therefore it does not meet the age inclusion criterion.

This is a resting-state fMRI study reporting connectivity biomarkers; no task-based social processing was performed. Although healthy controls are included, the study does not involve an fMRI social-related task as required by the review.

The study used ERP (event-related potentials), not fMRI. The abstract does not report any functional MRI scan during a social-related task or fMRI data from healthy adult participants, so it fails the fMRI inclusion criterion.

fMRI study of emotional facial expression processing (social-related task) including matched healthy young adult controls. Participants fall within adult age range and study is original research, not a review. Fits inclusion criteria.

fMRI study measuring neural response to social exclusion (a social-related task) in 21 healthy volunteers; directly addresses social processing. Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria of fMRI during social-related task with healthy participants.

Study uses fMRI with a social cognition paradigm, matching review objective. Abstract does not specify whether healthy control participants (age 17–65) were included; insufficient information to rule out eligibility. Include for full-text review to confirm presence of a healthy adult group.

fMRI study using action observation (mirror neuron system), which probes social cognition (perception/understanding of others). Includes a non-alexithymia control group of healthy adult participants. Fits inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults; no exclusion criteria met.

Resting-state fMRI in a sample of MS patients; no task-based social processing paradigm reported and no healthy control group described. Does not meet inclusion requirement of task-based fMRI with healthy adults (age 17–65).

fMRI study examining dynamic happy facial expression processing with social interaction cues (praise/blame), a social-cognition/social-related task. Includes a non-SPD group (n=14) serving as healthy participants. Abstract does not report participant ages; include for full-text review to confirm age range and other details.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants performing anticipation of others' actions in sport, which maps onto 'Perception and Understanding of Others' (social processing). Not a review/meta-analysis and meets age/group criteria (healthy players). Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text data extraction.

fMRI study examining processing of others' physical and emotional pain (perception/understanding of others), directly relevant to social-related processing. Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state participants were healthy adults; include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Functional MRI was used while healthy adult participants (omnivores, vegetarians, vegans) performed an empathy/affective appraisal task involving humans and animals—an explicit social-related processing task. Participants were healthy adults; study is original research, not a review. Meets inclusion criteria.

Study uses resting-state fMRI from ASD and control groups, not a task-based social processing paradigm. The review requires fMRI during a social-related task in healthy adults; this abstract describes passive/resting-state analyses and clinical comparisons, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

This is a resting-state fMRI study (no task performed) examining functional connectivity in BD and BPD; inclusion requires task-based fMRI of social-related processing. Although healthy controls are included, the absence of a social task means it does not meet the review’s primary inclusion criterion.

Resting-state fMRI study in children and adolescents with ASD (clinical population, age below target adult range) rather than task-based fMRI in healthy adults (17–65). Does not meet inclusion criteria.

This article is an ALE meta-analysis of fMRI studies (a meta-analysis), which meets the exclusion criterion 'systematic reviews or meta-analyses' and thus should be excluded based on the abstract alone.

fMRI performed during a face-discrimination task (social-related: perception/understanding of others). Study includes an age- and gender-matched healthy adult control group (chronological age-matched), satisfying the requirement for healthy participants likely within 17–65. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information for inclusion in the review.

This article is a meta-analysis of 12 fMRI studies rather than an original fMRI experiment with human participants performing a social task. Excluded per the criterion disallowing systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

This is a review article on genetics and neural systems in autism, not a primary fMRI study. The abstract does not report original fMRI data or task-based results in healthy adult participants. Excluded per exclusion criterion: systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

Study used fMRI in healthy adult participants (N=55 males, age within 17–65) during a social task (direct vs. averted gaze) probing social cognition; not a review. Satisfies inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI processing in healthy adults.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of body checking in females with anorexia nervosa (self-perception) but does not state whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included or clearly describe a social-related task. Insufficient information to determine eligibility from the abstract alone — include for full-text review.

fMRI was used while participants observed dynamic vs. static facial expressions (a social-processing task). The study includes age- and sex-matched typically developing controls (healthy participants). Abstract does not specify participant ages (17–65), so full text is needed to confirm adult age range.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of social judgments (a social-related task) meeting the review objective. However it does not specify whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included. Insufficient information to confirm the key sample criterion, so include for full-text review to verify presence of healthy participants.

Task-based fMRI of social processing (action-intention judgment) with a typically developing (healthy) control group included. The abstract does not report participant ages to confirm 17–65, so cannot fully confirm eligibility from abstract alone — include for full-text review.

fMRI was conducted during social cognition tasks (self/other representation) and the study included a healthy control group alongside BPD participants. This directly fits inclusion criteria of fMRI social-related processing with healthy adults; not a review.

Study II reports an fMRI experiment where 16 cocaine users and 16 healthy control adults completed a social-interaction/gaze paradigm during scanning, addressing social reward processing. Includes a healthy adult group and is an original empirical fMRI study (not a review).

Abstract describes application of fMRI to social cognition (joint attention, pro-social behavior) in human participants but lacks participant age and detailed methods. Not clearly a systematic review; insufficient information to confirm inclusion criteria, so include for full-text review.

fMRI study employing an emotion-recognition task (social cognition/perception of others) and includes a healthy control group (n=16). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Participants are children with benign childhood epilepsy (BCECTS), not healthy adults aged 17–65; no healthy adult group reported. Although an fMRI social task (fearful faces) was used, the population does not meet inclusion criteria.

Participants are adult male incarcerated offenders and the abstract does not report any healthy control group. Although task-based fMRI of social (self/other) processing was used, inclusion requires at least one group of healthy adults (17–65); criterion not met.

fMRI study of face emotion processing (a social cognition task) in a community sample comparing high vs. low social anhedonia. Participants appear to be healthy adults; task involves perception/understanding of others. Not a review. Meets inclusion criteria.

Resting-state fMRI was used (no social-related task). Inclusion requires a task-based fMRI during social processing. Although healthy volunteers and social constructs are discussed, the absence of a task means it fails the inclusion criterion.

fMRI during an ‘eyes’ task assessing theory of mind/social cognition — fits social-related processing. Abstract does not specify participant ages or whether a healthy adult group (offspring may be minors or high-risk). Insufficient information to exclude, so include for full-text review to confirm age range and presence of healthy adults.

This is a resting-state fMRI study; participants did not perform a social-related task. Inclusion requires task-based fMRI of social processing in healthy adults. Although healthy controls were included, the lack of a social task excludes the study.

This study used resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based social processing paradigm. Although it examines theory of mind in schizophrenia, it does not report task fMRI in healthy adults ages 17–65, so it does not meet the review’s inclusion criteria.

fMRI study in (presumably) healthy adult participants performing a social-related task (IAT with faces/names of politicians) probing perception/understanding of others and social attitudes; reports neural activations. Not a review. Meets inclusion criteria.

The study used resting-state fMRI after cTBS (scans taken at rest), not during a social-related task. It therefore does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring task-based fMRI measuring social processing in healthy adults.

The study used resting-state fMRI (no social-related task), so it does not meet the requirement of an fMRI scan during a social task. Participants are male adolescents (not clearly within the 17–65 adult range). Therefore it does not address the review objective.

fMRI study in healthy adults examining vicarious somatosensory activation when observing touch on others, addressing social perception/empathy (Perception and Understanding of Others). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Participants are adolescents (children/adolescents) including ASD; no group of healthy adults aged 17–65 is included. Study population falls outside the review’s age criterion and target (healthy adults).

Abstract reports an fMRI study using a social/mentalizing task (interactive Domino) and includes a healthy control group (n=30) of adults aged 18–34. This meets the review’s requirement for social-related fMRI in healthy participants; it is not a review or meta-analysis.

fMRI study of social understanding/social information processing in adults; includes a healthy matched control group (23 adults) alongside ASD group. Methods and population fit the review’s inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI social perspective-taking task is relevant, but the healthy group are adolescents (ages 12–19). Abstract does not specify how many healthy participants are ≥17. Insufficient information to confirm adult (17–65) healthy sample; include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

fMRI study with a social perception task (animations depicting social interactions) in a sample of healthy adult women (within 17–65). Neural responses to social processing were measured (oxytocin vs placebo). Not a review. Meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study where participants performed perception of nonverbal emotional social signals (voice and face), examining trait emotional intelligence and brain activation (pSTS). Involves healthy individual subjects and addresses social perception/understanding of others. Not a review. Fits meta-analysis objective of fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study investigating mirror neuron response and emotion processing—addresses social cognition/perception of others. Appears to involve healthy adult participants (not stated explicitly); not a review. Include for full-text to confirm participant ages and health status.

This record is a systematic review/meta-analysis protocol, not an original fMRI study of healthy adults performing social tasks. It meets the exclusion criterion (systematic reviews/meta-analyses), so it should be excluded from the primary-study meta-analysis.

fMRI study of self-evaluation (Perception and Understanding of Self), a social-related task; includes a healthy control group (13 matched controls, likely adults); not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports fMRI in 13 PTSD patients with pre/post therapy scans; no healthy control or healthy participant group (age 17–65) is described. Fails inclusion requirement of at least one healthy participant group.

This is a review article summarizing seven structural/functional MRI studies in ADHD samples (clinical populations), not an original fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. It therefore meets exclusion criteria (review) and does not report healthy adult participant data.

Event-related fMRI using a false-belief paradigm examines understanding others’ mental states (social cognition). The task is social-related (Perception/Understanding of Others). Abstract does not state participant ages explicitly but implies healthy individual differences; include for full-text to confirm sample characteristics and age range.

The study reports fMRI during a social task (facial emotion recognition) but participants are schizophrenia patients only (AT+SCT vs CG); no healthy participant group is reported. Inclusion requires at least one healthy group (age 17–65). Therefore exclude based on participant sample.

The study used fMRI with an emotion-recognition task (social processing) but included only schizophrenia outpatients randomized to interventions; no healthy participant group is reported. Inclusion requires at least one healthy adult group (17–65).

Study uses resting-state fMRI (rs-fMRI) for diagnostic classification of autism, not a task-based fMRI study of social processing. Participants are clinical (ASD) and the abstract does not report healthy adults performing social-related tasks. Does not meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports intrinsic/background functional connectivity (resting-state-like) in first-episode schizophrenia with healthy controls, not an fMRI task measuring social-related processing. Although healthy controls are included, no social task is described, so it does not meet the requirement for task-based social processing.

Abstract makes no mention of functional MRI or imaging methods and appears to describe behavioral findings in individuals with autism spectrum conditions; it does not clearly include a healthy adult group (age 17–65). Therefore it does not meet the fMRI-in-healthy-adults inclusion requirement.

Study used fMRI in healthy adult men performing social tasks (fear recognition, gaze processing, theory-of-mind tests), reporting neural activation and connectivity. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

Participants are pediatric/unaffected youth (pediatric bipolar disorder and at-risk youth), not healthy adults aged 17–65. Although fMRI face-emotion processing is social-related, the sample does not include healthy adults in the required age range, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

All participants described are children (boys), including cases with autism and child controls; no group of healthy adults aged 17–65 is included, so the study fails the age-related inclusion criterion.

fMRI study using face perception with emotional and neutral stimuli (a social-related task: perception/understanding of others) that includes a healthy control group. Meets inclusion criteria; not a review. Full text can confirm age range if needed.
Abstract indicates this article is a review of neuroimaging experiments rather than an original fMRI study with participants; it meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

Abstract text not provided; title suggests fMRI connectivity in Asperger’s but unclear whether task-based social processing was used or whether healthy adult controls (age 17–65) were included. Insufficient information to rule out inclusion — include for full-text review to confirm task and participant groups.

Study used resting-state fMRI (ALFF and RSFC) rather than a task-based social processing paradigm. Inclusion requires fMRI while participants performed a social-related task; this criterion is not met.

Abstract describes fMRI investigation of social cognition in schizophrenia out-patients (amygdala and STS). It does not clearly state whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included. Because inclusion requires at least one healthy group and the abstract is insufficient to determine this, include for full-text review to confirm presence of healthy participants and fMRI task details.

Original fMRI study using a social-contingency task probing self-relevant social reward processing. Includes a healthy neurotypical adult control group (24 TD adults) alongside ASD group; participants are adults (within 17–65). Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social-related processing in healthy adults. Not a review.

The study used resting-state fMRI (no social-task paradigm) and sampled adolescent males rather than healthy adults aged 17–65. It therefore does not meet the task-based fMRI requirement nor the adult age criterion.

fMRI study where participants made emotion (social) and age judgments of faces—task assesses perception/understanding of others. Includes a community control group of healthy adults. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient detail to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study using a social task (direct vs averted gaze) and includes a healthy comparison group. The abstract does not report participant ages (17–65 criterion unclear). No exclusion criteria met. Include for full-text review to confirm age eligibility and other details.
Participants are children (unaffected siblings and children with autism; matched control children), not healthy adults aged 17–65 required by the review. Does not meet age inclusion criterion.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=10) using viewing of funny versus non-funny cartoons, targeting humor/sense-of-humor—a form of social communication/perception. Meets review objective of social-related processing in healthy adults; not a review/meta-analysis.

fMRI study investigating neural correlates of promotion/prevention goal activation (self-regulation/social-cognitive processing) in human participants (n=16). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract does not state participant ages, so include for full-text review to confirm age range and health status.

fMRI study measuring brain responses while viewing emotional faces (social perception/understanding of others). Abstract implies healthy adult participants (no clinical sample mentioned); meets inclusion for social-related fMRI. Include for full-text to confirm participant ages/health.

fMRI study of biological motion perception (a social-cognition task) fits the review objective. Abstract does not explicitly state whether healthy control participants were included; because information is insufficient to confirm the required healthy adult group, include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

fMRI study examining agency attribution/social perception using animated shapes—directly relevant to social processing. Abstract does not state participant ages or health status, so inclusion criterion about healthy adults (17–65) cannot be confirmed from abstract alone. Include for full-text review to verify participant demographics and health.

fMRI was conducted during a facial emotion recognition task (social communication/perception), with thirty-seven healthy participants. This meets the review’s focus on fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults; no exclusion criteria apply.

Abstract discusses atypical network connectivity in ASD but does not specify whether an fMRI social-task was used or whether healthy adult controls (age 17–65) were included. No exclusion criteria met. Insufficient information to determine eligibility from abstract alone — include for full-text review.

fMRI study examining social processing (direct vs. averted gaze) that includes a typically developing (healthy) comparison group. The abstract does not report ages for the healthy participants (only 'adolescents and adults'), so age eligibility (17–65) cannot be confirmed from the abstract. Include for full-text review to verify participant ages and other details.

fMRI study of empathy for others' pain (perception/understanding of others), includes healthy control group; meets social-related task criterion and involves human participants. Not a review. Abstract indicates relevance for inclusion.

The abstract explicitly states this article is a review of findings (pharmacological fMRI and imaging genetics). It is a systematic review/meta-review article rather than an original fMRI study in participants, so it meets the exclusion criterion for reviews/meta-analyses.
This article is a systematic review of studies on the mirror neuron system in autism, not an original fMRI study of healthy adults. Exclusion criterion met: systematic review/meta-analysis.

This is a narrative review article summarizing three decades of affect neuropsychology rather than an original fMRI study with primary data. It does not report fMRI results from healthy adult participants performing social tasks; thus it meets the exclusion criterion for reviews.

The article is a systematic review of fMRI and DTI studies in autism spectrum disorder, not a primary fMRI study reporting original data in healthy adults. It meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses and provides no primary data on healthy participants aged 17–65.

Functional MRI was used in healthy adult participants (15 male, 15 female) during a Body Perception task comparing own vs other bodies, targeting perception/understanding of self and others — a social-related construct. This meets the inclusion criteria; not a review.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants examining neural activity during reflection on self and mother (social cognition: perception/understanding of self/others). Not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

All participants are adolescents (ASD 12–17; TD controls 12–18). No healthy adult group within the required 17–65 age range is clearly reported, so the study does not meet the inclusion criterion of a healthy adult sample.

This paper is a quantitative meta-analysis of fMRI studies (systematic review/meta-analysis). The review’s exclusion criteria explicitly exclude systematic reviews or meta-analyses, so it should be excluded despite addressing social communication in healthy adults.

Study used task-based functional MRI (modified prisoner's dilemma) probing social/ToM processing and included a healthy control group (n=20). Not a review. Age range not specified in abstract, but presence of healthy adult controls and task-based fMRI meets inclusion; include for full-text to confirm participant ages and other details.

This article is a systematic review of neuroimaging studies in patients with mood disorders. Exclusion criteria list systematic reviews/meta-analyses; also it focuses on patient groups rather than primary fMRI data in healthy adults, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

Empirical neuroimaging study examining processing of goal-directed actions (perception/understanding of others), which fits social-related processing. Abstract implies functional imaging of biological motion/EBA but lacks explicit participant demographics and modality details; include for full-text review to confirm fMRI methods and healthy adult sample.

Abstract concerns neural responses (fMRI task context) to social/affective stimuli (maternal response to child affect) and likely involves adult participants, but it does not state whether a healthy adult control group (ages 17–65) was included or provide task/fMRI details. Insufficient information to exclude; include for full-text review to confirm fMRI task and presence of healthy adult participants.

fMRI study of perception of emotional (fearful vs neutral) gestures — a social communication task. Abstract reports both autism and control groups, so includes healthy participants. Not a review or meta-analysis. Fits review objective of social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI study measuring brain responses to social awkwardness while participants watched a sitcom; examines social perception/mentalizing. Includes a control (healthy) participant group. Abstract does not specify participant ages, so include for full-text review to confirm ages meet 17–65.

fMRI study of pragmatic/social language processing (integration of speaker characteristics and message content) in adults; includes a matched healthy control group (ages likely within 17–65). Not a review or meta-analysis.

This is a review article summarizing literature on motor lateralization in autism, not an original fMRI study of social-related processing in healthy adults. It does not report fMRI task data in healthy 17–65-year-old participants. Reviews/meta-analyses meet exclusion criteria.

Abstract discusses social cognition/emotional intelligence but does not report whether fMRI during a social task or participant demographics. Insufficient information to determine inclusion; include for full-text review to confirm presence of task-based fMRI and healthy adult participants.

fMRI in healthy adult participants (male non-musicians) showing activation of ToM/social-cognition areas (PCC/PC, arMFC, TPJ) during aesthetic judgment; task implicates cognitive empathy/perception and understanding of others, meeting social-related processing criterion.

Abstract reports intranasal oxytocin effects on amygdala reactivity in humans and likely used neuroimaging; however it does not explicitly state the fMRI task or that participants performed a social-related task. Insufficient detail in abstract to determine task/social-processing criteria, so include for full-text review to confirm fMRI social task and participant details.

This study used resting-state fMRI in patients with social anxiety disorder and healthy controls, not a task-based fMRI paradigm probing social-related processing. Although healthy participants were included, no social task was performed, so it does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring fMRI during a social-related task.

Study examines multimodal neuroimaging of cognitive deficits in schizophrenia using the MCCB; no mention of fMRI during a social-related task or social processing in healthy adults. Focus is on patient cognitive biomarkers, not social tasks in healthy participants.

Abstract reports fMRI responses including a 'social communication' category but participants passively viewed natural movies; it is unclear whether this constitutes a social-related task and participant ages/health are not reported. Insufficient information to confirm inclusion criteria—include for full-text review.

This is a review article introducing a special issue, not an original fMRI study. It does not report functional MRI data from healthy adult participants; meets exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

Abstract reports fMRI in a sample of 14 females focusing on borderline personality disorder and ACEs; no healthy control group or healthy participants are mentioned. Inclusion requires at least one healthy adult group (age 17–65). Therefore the study does not meet the inclusion criteria based on the abstract.

The abstract describes a review article summarizing studies of social cognition in bipolar disorder rather than reporting original fMRI data in healthy adults. This meets the exclusion criterion for reviews/meta-analyses and lacks primary fMRI participants meeting inclusion criteria.

fMRI was used during facial emotion processing, a social-related task (perception/understanding of others). The study includes a healthy control group of adults alongside excessive smartphone users, meeting the criterion of at least one healthy participant group. Abstract provides sufficient information to assess inclusion.

Study used fMRI during social evaluations (self/friend perspective-taking) and includes a healthy comparison group. However participants are described as adolescents and ages are not specified; include for full-text review to confirm healthy participants meet the 17–65 adult age criterion.

Participants are pediatric (youth) and clinical (bipolar/high-risk), not healthy adults aged 17–65; abstract does not indicate an fMRI social-processing task. Does not meet the inclusion age/healthy-group and task criteria.

fMRI study using a social-emotional simulation task (imagining others' painful experiences) and reports a psychiatrically-healthy control group. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm participants are within 17–65 and meet other criteria.

Abstract mentions an fMRI study of deception (a social cognition construct) but gives insufficient detail about participant health status/ages and whether healthy adult controls were included. Include for full-text review to determine if healthy adults (17–65) participated and if the task meets social-processing criteria.

Study used fMRI during a social threat reactivity task (social processing) and includes a healthy control group of adults (age likely within 17–65). It is an original empirical study (not a review) and meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

This is a narrative/methodological review of magnetoencephalography (MEG), not an original functional MRI study of social-related processing in healthy adults; it therefore does not meet the inclusion criteria.

The study uses structural and functional MRI to classify ASD vs controls (ABIDE I) and does not describe any social-related task. It appears to use functional connectivity (likely resting-state) and includes clinical (ASD) and control groups, not a task-based fMRI of social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study where participants performed a social-related task (Multifaceted Empathy Test) assessing cognitive and emotional empathy. The sample includes 50 age- and gender-matched healthy control participants alongside BPD patients (adult participants). Not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion: fMRI during social processing task with a healthy adult group.
This article is an activation likelihood estimation meta-analysis (a meta-analysis), which meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews or meta-analyses. Exclude based on abstract alone.

Event-related fMRI study of evaluative judgments—a social-cognitive task involving self-referential processing/theory of mind. Abstract explicitly reports healthy age- and gender-matched control subjects described as young adults (within 17–65). Not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

The study recruited early adolescent girls (adolescents younger than 17), which falls outside the required adult age range (17–65) for inclusion. Although it is an fMRI study of social self-disclosure, the participant age disqualifies it.

Abstract reports an fMRI facial imitate/observe task (social processing) and includes people 'with and without severe mental illness', indicating a healthy control group is present. Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults; include for full-text review.

Participants are children (developmental ASD and typically developing children) rather than adults. The review requires at least one group of healthy participants aged 17–65; age criterion not met despite fMRI social-face task.

fMRI study of emotional prosody (social communication) comparing ASD participants and healthy controls; meets criterion of social-related task and includes a healthy control group. Ages not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm participant ages/details.

fMRI study of social cognition (social decisions from faces; affective processing) including healthy male and female participants and an ASD group. Fits inclusion: social-related task and healthy participants present. Abstract does not report participant ages; include for full-text review to confirm ages (17–65).

Study used fMRI while participants viewed social (faces, people) vs nonsocial images (a social-related perceptual task). It included a healthy comparison group (n=14) alongside a schizophrenia group, satisfying requirement for healthy adults. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

This article is a narrative review of the neurobiology of social phobia, not an original fMRI study reporting functional MRI during a social task in human participants. It meets the exclusion criterion for reviews/meta-analyses, so exclude.

Abstract does not report participants, age range, or that fMRI was actually used with healthy adults. Topic (reward in autism) may involve social processing and could include healthy control group, but information is insufficient to determine eligibility. Include for full-text review to confirm whether an fMRI social-related task was performed and whether healthy adult participants (17–65) were included.

fMRI study with healthy (‘‘normal volunteers’’) participants performing social-cognitive tasks (identifying emotions and attributing social causes). This addresses perception/understanding of others and meets inclusion; not a review. Full text can confirm participant ages if needed.

Abstract is insufficient to determine if a task-based social fMRI was used or if a healthy adult control group (age 17–65) was included. Title suggests adults with autism and oxytocin manipulation, but details about task vs resting-state and presence of healthy participants are unclear. Include for full-text review to assess eligibility.

fMRI study presenting narratives about protected values to 78 healthy American, Chinese, and Iranian participants, probing social-cognitive processes (value/moral and social cognition). Meets inclusion: task is social-related and uses fMRI in (presumably) healthy adults. Abstract lacks explicit age range—include for full-text to confirm ages and health status.
Participants are adolescents aged 11.1–15.5 years; inclusion requires healthy adults aged 17–65. Although the study used fMRI during a social-empathy task, the sample does not meet the age criterion.

Study reports fMRI of implicit interpersonal space/affiliation processing with a social vs non-social task and reports neural results. Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state they were healthy adults, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility (age 17–65, healthy).

Abstract is a conceptual primer/review on brain-imaging principles in social neuroscience; it does not report an fMRI experiment, participants, or social task data. Not eligible for inclusion as an fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study in healthy adult practitioners using compassion-meditation and reappraisal while viewing others in distress—addresses social/affiliative processing (perception/understanding of others). Not a review. Meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study examining social communication (L2 communicative speech vs description) in a group of healthy adult native Japanese speakers. Task involves social interaction/theory-of-mind and communication processes, meeting the review’s social-related fMRI criterion. Not a review article.

Study reports two case studies of young children with autism spectrum disorder; no healthy adult (age 17–65) participants or group are included. Does not meet the population criterion for this review.

This is a review article summarizing MRI findings in autism (not an original fMRI study of healthy adults). It meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses and does not report primary fMRI data from healthy 17–65 participants.

The study examines facial emotion processing (a social cognition task) and includes healthy subjects alongside first-episode psychosis patients. The abstract refers to neurofunctional/brain functioning but does not explicitly state fMRI or participant ages; information is insufficient to confirm imaging modality or age range, so include for full-text review.

This is a resting-state fMRI study with no social-related task; participants include ASD and controls but no task-based social processing was performed. Therefore it does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring an fMRI social task.

fMRI social task (Cyberball) with a healthy comparison group is reported. However participants are described as adolescents and ages are not specified; because age eligibility (17–65) cannot be confirmed from abstract, include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

Abstract reports an fMRI task probing amygdala responsiveness to social-phobia-related verbal stimuli (a social-related task) and includes a matched healthy control group (110 controls). Thus it meets inclusion criteria; age not specified but sample described as adults—include for full-text review.

This is a structural MRI volumetric study (manual tracing of fusiform gyrus) in 22q11.2 deletion syndrome and healthy controls; no task-based fMRI of social processing is reported, so it does not meet inclusion.

This paper is an introductory/overview article for a special issue, not an original empirical fMRI study. The abstract describes theory/method breadth and other articles but does not report fMRI data from healthy adult participants; thus it does not meet inclusion criteria.
Participants are children (age 7–13); no group of healthy adults aged 17–65 is included. Although fMRI was used for social processing, the sample falls outside the required age range for the review.

The article is a neuroimaging review (Sexual medicine reviews) discussing advances and limitations of fMRI studies of female sexual desire/HSDD rather than reporting an original fMRI experiment in healthy adults. It meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

Participants are children with ASD and typically developing children (not adults aged 17–65). The meta-analysis requires healthy adult participants (17–65); therefore this study does not meet the population criterion.

Functional MRI study examining perception of social cues (fearful faces with gaze) — a social-related task — that includes a matched healthy adult control group in addition to ASD participants. Not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study of facial emotion processing (a social-related task). Abstract does not state whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included; insufficient information to rule out presence of healthy participants. Include for full-text review to confirm sample composition and eligibility.

Study used fMRI while participants processed idiographic negative self-beliefs and implemented reappraisal/acceptance—tasks probing perception/understanding of self (a social-related construct). Sample consisted of healthy adult participants and the abstract reports task-based BOLD responses. Not a review or meta-analysis.

The study reports an fMRI task on social cognition (happy face recognition) in patients with bipolar disorder; the abstract does not mention any healthy control group. Inclusion requires at least one healthy participant group aged 17–65, so it fails the inclusion criteria.

fMRI study with healthy participants performing a third-party punishment task tapping mentalizing and evaluation of others (social cognition). Fits social-related processing criteria. Abstract does not specify participant ages (17–65), so include for full-text review to confirm age range and other details.

Functional MRI study examining attentional orienting to gaze cues (social communication/perception of others). Abstract reports fMRI neural activity related to social cues and does not indicate clinical populations. Participant ages not specified—include for full-text review to confirm demographics and health status.

The abstract reports data collected within a chronic traumatic brain injury population and does not mention any healthy control group (ages 17–65). Although it uses fMRI and faces (social stimuli), the absence of healthy participants means it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

This abstract describes a narrative review of mirror neuron dysfunction in autism, summarizing evidence (fMRI, TMS, EEG) and discussing interventions. It is not an original fMRI study in healthy adults and appears to focus on ASD populations; it meets the exclusion criterion for reviews and does not include healthy adult fMRI data.

Abstract reports an fMRI study examining altruistic (prosocial) choice and neural encoding in regions (precuneus, TPJ) implicated in social cognition. It uses healthy adult participants likely, but participant age/health not specified in abstract. Meets the review objective (social-related processing). Include for full-text review to confirm participant characteristics and ages.

Abstract reports an original fMRI experiment in which healthy participants viewed human and robot avatars with belief manipulation, probing person perception and mentalizing (social cognition). This fits the review objective (fMRI of social processing in healthy adults). Not a systematic review/meta-analysis.

fMRI study with 30 healthy adult participants performing a social-related gaze/action control task (direct vs averted gaze; social cognition and action control). Fits constructs of social perception/understanding of others. Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants examining social cognition (mentalizing, motor resonance, recognition of others' intentions) while observing a demonstrator. Task clearly involves perception/understanding of others, meeting the review's inclusion criteria.

This is an overview/narrative review of molecular neuroimaging of emotional decision-making, not an original fMRI study. The abstract reports no functional MRI conducted on human participants performing a social-related task or participant ages, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI was conducted during a social ball‑tossing (exclusion/inclusion) task assessing social interaction processing; the study includes a healthy control group. No exclusion criteria are met. Age range not specified in abstract but participants were matched for age, so include for full‑text review to confirm ages.

Abstract reports fMRI hemodynamic responses to child stimuli in neural regions linked to social cognition, assessing maternal social-related behavior. Participant health status and ages are not specified in the abstract, so inclusion cannot be confirmed from abstract alone. Include for full-text review to verify that at least one group are healthy adults (17–65) and that the task is social-related.

This fMRI study examines speech repetition (word/pseudoword) and age-related changes in RT/BOLD timing. The task is motor/speech production focused and does not involve social-processing or social-communication paradigms or social cognitive measures in the abstract. Therefore it does not meet the social-related task inclusion criterion.

fMRI used for cognitive rehabilitation in patients with mild TBI performing music/piano tasks; task is not a social-related processing task and participants are clinical (mTBI), not healthy adults. Does not meet the review objective or inclusion criteria.

fMRI study using a social approval task (social reward processing) with a healthy control group (15 controls) and patients. Addresses social-related processing in humans. Age range not reported in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm age criteria.

This is an fMRI study of prosodic (linguistic and emotional) speech, which relates to social communication. The abstract does not state whether a healthy adult control group (age 17–65) was included. Insufficient information to determine inclusion, so include for full-text review.

fMRI study of theory-of-mind (social cognition) including a healthy control group; task involves social intentions and ToM processing. Abstract meets social-related fMRI criterion; not a review. Recommend full-text review to confirm participant ages and detailed methods.

All participants were children (one HFA child, one Asperger’s child, three normal children); no healthy adult (age 17–65) group is included, so it fails the requirement of at least one healthy adult group for inclusion.

fMRI study of social communication (L2 vs L1 communicative speech) in healthy adult native Japanese speakers; task involves social interactive communication and theory-of-mind/action-simulation processes. Meets inclusion (social-related fMRI task in healthy adults). No exclusion criteria apply.

fMRI study using an empathy-for-pain paradigm (social-related processing) with both autistic and healthy control participants. Meets inclusion: functional MRI during a social task and includes a healthy adult control group. Not a review or meta-analysis.

The paper is a narrative review summarizing psychopharmacological and fMRI research rather than reporting new primary fMRI data. It meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses and does not describe an fMRI scan during a social task on human participants.

Human fMRI study of visual social processing (sensitivity to spatial relations between two bodies: facing vs nonfacing) in human participants; addresses social perception in healthy adults and is an original empirical study, not a review.

fMRI study probing social cognition (eye gaze, face processing, Theory of Mind, action understanding) and includes a neurotypical (healthy) control group. Age range not reported in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm participants are within 17–65.

Original fMRI study of audiovisual speech perception (social communication). Includes an age- and gender-matched healthy control group (adults implied). Not a review or meta-analysis. Meets criteria for fMRI social-related processing with healthy participants.

The study used structural MRI covariance analysis rather than task-based functional MRI. It does not report an fMRI scan during a social-related task, so it fails the inclusion criterion requiring fMRI task data. Although controls are likely included, the lack of fMRI prevents inclusion.

The study reports a functional MRI experiment examining memory for neutral faces embedded in goal-relevant vs goal-irrelevant social situations and reports activation in social-processing regions (STS). This is a social-related task in humans and fits inclusion criteria; no exclusion criteria met. (Participant health/age not explicitly stated but typical for this literature.)

Abstract reports brain imaging of theory of mind and empathy in schizophrenia but does not specify that functional MRI was used or that a healthy adult control group (age 17–65) was included. Insufficient information to confirm inclusion criteria; include for full-text review to determine whether fMRI and healthy participants are present.

fMRI study of action recognition/perception of others (social cognition). Uses healthy participants viewing actions; measures brain regions distinguishing actions — fits ‘Perception and Understanding of Others’ social-related construct. Not a review.

fMRI was used during social-related tasks (action observation/execution and action understanding linked to theory of mind/MNS). Study includes a healthy control group of adults. No exclusion criteria met in abstract.

fMRI BOLD study where participants rated faces for trustworthiness (a social perception task), and the sample includes healthy control participants. Not a review; meets inclusion criteria. Age range not specified—include for full-text confirmation.

Human fMRI study examining neural representation of action meaning (perception/understanding of others), clearly relevant to social-related processing. Not a review. Abstract does not state participant ages/health explicitly, so include for full-text review to confirm sample meets 17–65 healthy adult criterion.

fMRI data were acquired at rest (resting-state functional MRI) rather than during a social-related task. Inclusion requires task-based fMRI during social processing; therefore exclude based on abstract.

Study concerns self- and other-processing (a social cognition construct) and reports brain imaging; abstract does not specify whether fMRI was used or whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included. Insufficient information to exclude—include for full-text review to confirm imaging modality and presence of healthy participants.

This is a review/perspective article discussing the field of social neuroscience, not an original fMRI study. Abstract contains no methods, participant group, or task data. It meets the exclusion criterion of being a review, so exclude.

The study uses fMRI to investigate executive control and hub architecture in autism spectrum disorder, not social-related processing. Although it likely includes healthy control participants, the task and outcomes focus on executive function rather than a social task; thus it does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring a social-related fMRI task.

fMRI study uses a social interaction task (reaction-time competition with opponents; provocation/punishment) relevant to social processing. Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicit healthy status, so inclusion cannot be confirmed from abstract alone. Include for full-text review to verify participant characteristics and eligibility.

Participants are described as youth (children/adolescents: 31 with DBDs and 27 typically developing youth), not adults. The review requires healthy participants aged 17–65, so the sample does not meet the age criterion.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants performing an affective creativity task (generating alternative appraisals for anger-evoking events) that likely involves social/emotional cognition. Abstract does not explicitly state a social task, so include for full-text review to confirm relevance to social processing.

The study used resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based fMRI of social processing. Although social cognition tests and healthy controls were included, the inclusion criterion requires an fMRI scan conducted while participants performed a social-related task, which is not met.

Study used fMRI (combined fMRI-PET) while mothers viewed/reacted to their infants (an affiliative/social processing task). Participants are adult mothers (healthy group). The paper reports original data, not a review, and directly addresses social/attachment processing.

fMRI was used to measure brain responses while participants evaluated body odour peptides (self vs non-self), a social-related task involving perception/understanding of self and social communication. Participants appear to be healthy volunteers; meets review objective.

The study investigates memory control and recognition processes using fMRI (likelihood cueing recognition task) with no social-related task or measures of social processing. Thus it does not meet the inclusion criterion of social-related processing in healthy adults.

The article is a review summarizing the authors' research program rather than reporting original fMRI experiments. It meets the exclusion criterion (systematic reviews/meta-analyses/reviews) and thus should be excluded.

Mega-analysis of four task-based fMRI studies in which participants considered others' mental states (social cognition). This is empirical fMRI research (not a review/meta-analysis) and clearly addresses social processing; likely involves healthy adult participants. Meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study measuring neural responses during voice-based identity and emotion recognition (social perception) in human participants. Includes a group of healthy sighted adults and fits ‘perception and understanding of others’ construct. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text data extraction.

Participants are children/adolescents (age range ~5.5–19.7, mean ~11–12), not healthy adults aged 17–65. Also the study used resting-state measures rather than an fMRI social task, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

Task-based fMRI assessed amygdala functional connectivity during an emotional task (socially-relevant processing), and the study includes a healthy control group (n=25) of adults. The task and reported effects relate to social cognition/self-consciousness, meeting inclusion criteria.

Resting-state fMRI study in a clinical sample (MDD) with no healthy control group and no social task-based fMRI. Does not meet inclusion criteria requiring task-based social processing in healthy adults.

Resting-state fMRI study with no social task performed; inclusion requires functional MRI during a social-related task. Although healthy controls are included, absence of task-based social processing means it does not meet the primary inclusion criterion.

Abstract reports an fMRI-pupillometry study examining pupil-mimicry effects on trust and recruitment of the theory-of-mind network—clearly a social-processing task. It is an original empirical fMRI study (not a review). While ages/health status aren't explicitly stated, it likely involves healthy adults; include for full-text review to confirm participant details.
Resting-state fMRI (no social-related task) and participants are young children (age 3–7), not healthy adults 17–65; therefore does not meet inclusion criteria for task-based fMRI in adults.

Abstract states all subjects were entering psychotherapy for depression and/or anxiety and describes two clinical groups (intervention vs therapy-as-usual). No group of healthy adults is reported. Inclusion requires at least one healthy participant group (age 17–65). Therefore exclude.

The study reports fMRI data collected while participants performed the Prisoner’s Dilemma, a social interaction task, and analyzes neural responses (VTA, amygdala) to cooperative/non-cooperative interactions. No indication it’s a review or that participants are clinical only; fits inclusion of healthy adult fMRI social-processing studies. Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages/health status.

fMRI study examining emotional reactions to outcomes during social decision-making (social scenarios), clearly addressing social processing (regret, disappointment, relief). Not a review/meta-analysis. Participants described as late adolescents and young adults—likely healthy and within the 17–65 range; include for full-text review to confirm exact ages and health status.

This is a study protocol for a behavioral intervention (BEATVIC) in individuals with psychotic disorders; the abstract does not report any fMRI scanning, social-processing tasks, or inclusion of healthy adult participants. Therefore it does not meet the fMRI social-processing healthy adult criterion.

fMRI was used during an audio-visual social-norm inference task (judging others’ emotional vocal reactions), which is a social-related process (perception/understanding of others). The study includes a matched typically developing adult control group (healthy adults). Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract indicates adult participants. Therefore it meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study using a Theory of Mind (social cognition) task with both adults with Tourette syndrome and a matched healthy control group. Meets criterion of social task and includes healthy participants (adults).

fMRI study of gesture-speech integration (social communication). Includes healthy participant groups (n=19 replicated sample; matched healthy controls n=17), fitting the review’s focus on social processing in healthy adults. Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text data extraction.

fMRI study using the Trust Game (social decision-making) assessing neural correlates of interpreting/exploiting others—fits social-related processing. Not a review. Abstract does not specify participant health/ages; insufficient to confirm but likely healthy adults, so include for full-text screening to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study using a Theory of Mind paradigm (social cognition). Abstract reports a matched control group (n=13), indicating at least one healthy participant group. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm participants meet 17–65 age criterion and health status.

Human fMRI study investigating how learning about another’s choices alters value representations in medial prefrontal cortex—clearly social-related processing and not a review. Abstract does not specify participant ages or health status; include for full-text review to confirm participants meet healthy adult (17–65) criterion.

fMRI study of observation and mental imagery of face and limb movements addresses social communication and perception of others (social-related processing). Human participants implied; abstract does not explicitly report ages/health status, so include for full-text review to confirm participant ages (17–65) and health.

Study examines resting-state functional connectivity in cocaine-dependent individuals (clinical sample), not task-based fMRI of social processing; no social-related task or healthy adult group reported. Does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study investigating social communication (‘vitality forms’) in speech and action; tasks involve perception and simulation of social aspects. Participants are described without clinical populations. Meets the review objective of social-related fMRI processing in humans; no exclusion criteria met.

fMRI was used while participants explicitly and implicitly processed emotional facial expressions (a social-related task). The study includes a healthy control group (adults, mean ages 27–37) within the 17–65 range. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

The abstract explicitly describes an activation likelihood estimation (ALE) meta-analysis of 125 human fMRI studies. This is a meta-analysis/systematic review, which meets the exclusion criterion. No full-text needed to determine exclusion.

Resting-state fMRI parcellation study; no task or social-related processing reported. Focus is on intrinsic lateral frontal cortex organization, not social cognition tasks, so does not meet inclusion criteria.

This article is a narrative review of neuroimaging literature on face processing in autism, not an original fMRI study reporting data from participants. It meets the exclusion criterion (systematic reviews/meta-analyses), and does not present fMRI data from healthy adults performing social tasks.

Study used resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based social processing paradigm. Inclusion requires an fMRI scan performed while participants engaged in a social-related task. Although healthy control participants are included, the absence of a social task during scanning warrants exclusion based on the abstract.

Abstract reports an fMRI experiment investigating inhibition of imitative behaviour and social-cognitive processes (mental state attribution), with neural activations in aFMC and TPJ. It is an empirical fMRI study relevant to social processing and not a review; participant details not stated, so include for full-text confirmation of healthy adult sample.

The task involves active listening to human footsteps and reports involvement of the posterior superior temporal sulcus (a social cognition area), indicating social perception/processing. The abstract does not specify participant health status or ages, so insufficient detail to confirm inclusion criteria fully; include for full-text review to verify healthy adult sample (17–65).

Functional MRI was used while participants performed a social appraisal task (judging faces with emotional expressions). The study includes a healthy control group alongside a psychosis group. Abstract does not state participant ages, so full text should be checked to confirm ages 17–65, but criteria for social task and presence of healthy adults are met.

Functional MRI study examining emotional speech prosody (social communication) in 22 participants performing explicit emotion categorization and implicit tasks. Involves healthy adult subjects and measures social-related processing; not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports fMRI in young adults performing tasks with peer observation (social influence), a social-related manipulation (Stoplight peer observation). Participants are healthy young adults within 17–65 and this is an original empirical study, not a review. Fits inclusion criteria.

This publication is a meta-analysis/systematic review of fMRI studies rather than an original fMRI study with participants. It therefore meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

Abstract does not state that fMRI was used or that healthy adult controls (ages 17–65) were included. The topic (visual personal familiarity) is potentially social, but insufficient information to determine eligibility from abstract alone. Include for full-text review to confirm imaging modality and participant groups.

Abstract is a conceptual/theoretical synthesis discussing EP and ToM across levels and referencing lesion and fMRI studies; it does not report an original fMRI experiment in healthy adults. It appears to be a review article, meeting the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

This is a narrative review/chapter summarizing amygdala findings (including fMRI) across neurodevelopmental disorders rather than an original fMRI study of healthy adults performing a social task. It meets the exclusion criterion for reviews/meta-analyses.

This article is a quantitative meta-analysis of neuroimaging studies rather than an original fMRI experiment. The exclusion criteria specify systematic reviews or meta-analyses, so it should be excluded despite addressing social processes.

Abstract reports comparison of neural responses to socially salient stimuli between Tourette patients and healthy controls, indicating social cognition processing. However it does not explicitly state that fMRI was used or provide participant ages. Include for full-text review to confirm an fMRI task and that healthy participants are aged 17–65.

Abstract reports an fMRI study probing perception/understanding of others (social cognition) with neural activity in mentalizing network. Participant health status/ages not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample (17–65).

Study investigates recognition memory and emotional valence effects (nonconscious memory, repetition suppression/enhancement) using visual stimuli, not social-related processing. Does not address social constructs (affiliation, social communication, self/other perception). Healthy adults included, but primary task is memory/emotion rather than social; exclude.
This article is an activation likelihood estimation (ALE) meta-analysis of fMRI studies (a meta-analysis). The exclusion criteria explicitly remove systematic reviews or meta-analyses.

fMRI study with an experimental social task contrasting anticipation of touching an animate (human) vs inanimate target, addressing social behavior; conducted in healthy volunteers; not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

Study examined functional connectivity in preschool-aged children with autism spectrum disorder; no healthy adult (age 17–65) participant group is included. Also does not describe an fMRI social-task in healthy adults. Exclude.

Study reports fMRI of language comprehension in schizophrenia patients (cohort comprised purely of patients) and does not describe any healthy adult group; task concerns language semantics, not social-related processing. Therefore it does not meet inclusion criteria.

Participants are children and adolescents (not healthy adults aged 17–65), and the fMRI task examines basic auditory/visual perceptual processing (pitch and dot location) rather than an explicit social-related task. Therefore it does not meet the review’s population or task inclusion criteria.

The fMRI task involved hypnotic suggestion-induced pain and modulation of sensory areas, not a social-cognitive or social-interaction task. Although suggestion is noted as relevant to social interaction, the study investigates sensory modulation during hypnosis rather than social processing; insufficient evidence of a social-related task in the abstract.

Human fMRI study examining neural responses to disgust facial expressions and activity in regions linked to social cognition (perception/understanding of others). Abstract does not state participant ages/health explicitly, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

The study used rTMS to investigate self-other discrimination, not functional MRI. It does not report an fMRI scan during a social task, so it does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring fMRI data.

fMRI tasks described (verbal fluency and nonsense sentence completion) are language/executive, not clearly social-processing tasks. The abstract focuses on PAX6 mutation subjects and does not confirm a healthy adult control group. Does not meet inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

Study reports fMRI responses in children with autism spectrum disorder; no group of healthy adults (age 17–65) is reported. Does not meet the requirement of at least one healthy adult participant group.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants processing concrete ('how') and abstract ('why') aspects of human actions. The task involves understanding others' actions/intentions (Perception and Understanding of Others), fitting the review's social-related processing criterion. No exclusion criteria apparent.

This paper is an activation likelihood estimation (ALE) meta-analysis of 16 fMRI studies. The exclusion criteria specify systematic reviews or meta-analyses; therefore it should be excluded despite being on relevant social face-processing topics.

Abstract reports an fMRI paradigm measuring brain response to fearful faces (social-emotional processing) and includes a matched healthy control group of adult males. This meets inclusion criteria of fMRI during social-related task with at least one healthy adult group.

fMRI study with 29 healthy adult participants observing others' actions, addressing perception and understanding of others (social cognition/social communication). Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract clearly reports task and healthy sample, meeting inclusion criteria.

Abstract does not specify that functional MRI was used nor whether a healthy control group (ages 17–65) was included. Insufficient information in abstract to determine eligibility; include for full-text review to confirm imaging modality and participant groups.

Task-based fMRI study investigating social judgments of persons (perception/understanding of others). Abstract reports original experimental data (not a review) and likely involves healthy adult participants. Therefore meets inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

Resting-state fMRI in children (ASD with language impairment and typically developing children), not a task-based social-processing study in healthy adults 17–65. Does not address social-related task fMRI in healthy adult participants.
Participants are adolescents (age range 8–19) with no distinct adult (17–65) group reported. The study does not clearly include a healthy adult sample meeting the review’s age criterion.

Study uses fMRI during a social-cognitive task (visual perspective-taking). Abstract does not clearly state inclusion of a healthy control group aged 17–65. Because participant details are insufficient to determine eligibility, include for full-text review to confirm presence of healthy adults.

This is a structural MRI study of cortical thickness and structural covariance in ASD from a multicenter dataset, not a task-based fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. It focuses on anatomical differences including clinical (ASD) groups and children/adults; no social-related fMRI task in healthy 17–65 participants is reported.

Study used fMRI to probe neural mechanisms of persuasion/expert influence, a social-related process (social interaction, trust, attitude). It reports primary neuroimaging results in humans and is not a review. Participant ages not specified in abstract, but the study involves healthy human subjects; include for full-text review to confirm age range and health status.

fMRI was used to examine facial emotion recognition (a social cognitive task) and the study included a neurotypical adult control group alongside individuals with Asperger syndrome, meeting the requirement of at least one healthy participant group. No exclusion criteria apply.

Abstract reports fMRI studies of emotion perception using dynamic audio-visual stimuli, a social cognition task (perception/understanding of others). It describes fMRI block-design comparisons of emotional vs neutral and bimodal vs unimodal. The abstract does not state participant health status or ages; because it meets the review topic and may include healthy adults, include for full-text review to confirm sample characteristics.

fMRI study of sentence comprehension that includes factors labeled 'social interaction' among event types, suggesting social-content processing. Abstract does not report participant health status or age range nor confirm that task specifically targeted social cognition.
